westward ho by charles kingsley to rajah sir james brooke kcb george augustus selwyn dd bishop of new zealand book be dedicated by one who unknown to have other method of expressing admiration reverence for character that type of english virtue at once manful godly practical enthusiastic prudent self sacrificing have tried to depict in page have exhibited in form even purer more heroic than in have drest than in be exhibited by worthy whom elizabeth without distinction of rank age gathered round in ever glorious war of great reign c k february content introduction how mr oxenham saw white bird ii how amyas came home first time iii of two gentleman of wale how hunted with hound yet ran with deer iv two way of being crost in love v clovelly court in olden time vi combes of far west vii true tragical history of mr john oxenham of plymouth viii how noble brotherhood of rose be founded ix how amyas kept christmas day x how mayor of bideford baited hook with own flesh xi how eustace leigh met pope legate xii how bideford bridge dined at annery house xiii how golden hind came home again xiv how salvation yeo slew king of gubbings xv how mr john brimblecombe understood nature of oath xvi most chivalrous adventure of good ship rose xvii how came to barbados found men therein xviii how took pearl at margarita xix what befell at la guayra xx spanish bloodhound english mastiff xxi how took communion under tree at higuerote xxii inquisition in indie xxiii bank of meta xxiv how amyas be tempted of devil xxv how took gold train how took great galleon xxvii how salvation yeo found little maid again xxviiihow amyas came home third time xxix how virginia fleet be stopped by queen command xxx how admiral john hawkins testified against croaker xxxi great armada xxxii how amyas threw sword into sea xxxiii how amyas let apple fall westward ho chapter how mr oxenham saw white bird hollow oak palace be heritage sea who have travelled through delicious scenery of north devon must need know little white town of bideford slope upwards from broad tide river paved with yellow sand many arched old bridge where salmon wait for autumn flood toward pleasant upland on west above town hill close in cushioned with deep oak wood through jut here there crag of fern fringed slate below lower open more more in softly rounded knoll fertile square of red green till sink into wide expanse of hazy flat rich salt marsh rolling sand hill where torridge join sister taw together flow quietly toward broad surge of bar everlasting thunder of long atlantic swell pleasantly old town stand there beneath soft italian sky fanned day night by fresh ocean breeze forbids alike keen winter frost fierce thunder heat of midland pleasantly have stood there for now perhaps eight hundred year since first grenville cousin of conqueror returning from conquest of south wale drew round trusty saxon serf free norse rover with golden curl dark silurian briton from swansea shore mingled blood still give to seaward folk of next county strength intellect even in levelling day peculiar beauty of face form at time whereof write bideford be not merely pleasant country town whose quay be haunted by few coasting craft be one of chief port of england furnished seven ship to fight armada even more than century afterwards say chronicler sent more vessel to northern trade than port in england saving strange juxtaposition london topsham be centre of local civilization enterprise small perhaps compared with vast effort of present day who dare despise day of small thing if have proved to be dawn of mighty one be to sea life labor of bideford dartmouth topsham plymouth then petty place many little western town england owes foundation of naval commercial glory be men of devon drake hawkins gilbert raleigh grenvilles oxenhams host more of forgotten worthy whom will learn one day to honor a deserve to whom owes commerce colony very existence for have not first crippled by west indian raid ill gotten resource of spaniard then crushed last huge effort in britain glorious fight of what have be by now popish appanage of world tyranny a cruel a heathen rome far more devilish be in memory of men voyage battle faith valor heroic life le heroic death that write book if now then will seem to warm into style somewhat too stilted pompous let be excused for subject sake fit rather to have be sung than said to have proclaimed to true english heart not a novel a epic man may yet gird to write same great message song of troy persian war trophy of marathon salami spoke to heart of true greek of old one bright summer afternoon in year of grace tall fair boy came lingering along bideford quay in scholar gown with satchel slate in hand watching wistfully shipping sailor till just after have passed bottom of high street came opposite to one of many tavern looked out upon river in open bay window sat merchant gentleman discoursing over afternoon draught of sack outside door be gathered group of sailor listening earnestly to one who stood in midst boy alive for sea news must need go up to take place among sailor lad who be peeping whispering under elbow of men so came in for following speech delivered in loud bold voice with strong devonshire accent fair sprinkling of oath if believe go see stay here grow over blue mould tell a be gentleman saw with eye so did salvation yeo there through window in lower room measured heap a be christened man seventy foot long ten foot broad twelve foot high of silver bar bar between thirty forty pound weight say captain drake lad of devon have brought to mouth of world treasure house be own fault now if sweep out a empty a stock fish ' why did bring of home then mr oxenham why be there to help to carry must have brought 'em away safe enough young drake have broke door abroad already captain drake go off in dead faint when came to look have wound in leg might have laid three finger in boot be full of blood have be for hour more heart of be that that never knew till dropped then brother got away to boat kicking struggling bidding let go on with fight though step took in sand be in pool of blood so got off tell ye son of shotten herring be worth more to save than dirty silver for silver can get again brave boy there be more fish in sea than ever came out of more silver in nombre de dios than must pave street in west country of such captain a franky drake heaven never make one at time if lose good bye to england luck say who agree let choose weapon be man who delivered harangue be tall sturdy personage with florid black bearded face bold restless dark eye who leaned with crossed leg arm akimbo against wall of house seemed in eye of schoolboy very magnifico prince duke at least be dressed contrary to sumptuary law of time in suit of crimson velvet little worse perhaps for wear by side be long spanish rapier brace of dagger gaudy enough about hilt finger sparkled with ring have two three gold chain about neck large earring in ear behind one of red rose be stuck jauntily enough among glossy black curl on head be broad velvet spanish hat in instead of feather be fastened with great gold clasp whole quezal bird whose gorgeous plumage of fretted golden green shone like one entire precious stone a finished speech took off said hat looking at bird in look ye lad did ever see such fowl a before be bird old indian king of mexico let one wear own self therefore wear john oxenham of south tawton for sign to brave lad of devon a spaniard be master of indian be master of spaniard replaced hat murmur of applause followed one hinted that doubted spaniard be too many for too many how many men did take nombre de dios with seventy three be more when sailed out of plymouth sound before saw spanish main half be gastados used up a don say with scurvy in port pheasant captain rawse of cowes fell in with gave thirty hand more with handful lad only fifty three in picked lock of new world whom did lose trumpeter who stood braying like as in middle of square instead of taking care of neck like christian tell spaniard be rank coward a bully be pray to woman idolatrous rascal wonder fight like woman be right captain sang out tall gaunt fellow who stood close to one westcountry man can fight two easterlings easterling can beat three don day eh lad of devon for o be herring good brown beef cider cream so white o be making of jolly devon lad for to play eke to fight come said oxenham come along who list who list who will make fortune oh who will join jolly mariner who will join say o to fill pocket with good red goold by sailing on sea o who will list cried gaunt man again now be time have got forty men to plymouth now ready to sail minute get back want dozen out of bideford men just boy two then be off away make fortune go to heaven body in sea so deep soul in heaven to rest where valiant seaman one hereafter will be blest now said oxenham wo let plymouth men say that bideford men dare follow north devon against south be who will join who will join be step of way after sailing a smooth a duck pond a soon a be past cape finisterre will run clovelly herring boat there back for wager of twenty pound never ship bucketful way who will join think be buying pig in poke know road salvation yeo here too who be gunner mate a well a do narrow sea better ask to show chart of now see if tell over ruttier a well a drake on gaunt man pulled from under arm great white buffalo horn covered with rough etching of land sea held up to admiring ring see here boy behold pictur of place dra'ed out so natural a ever be life got mun from portingal down to azores 'd pricked mun out pricked mun out wheresoever 'd sailed whatsoever 'd seen take mun in hand now simon evans take mun in hand look mun over will warrant will know way in five minute so well a ever shark in sea horn be passed from hand to hand while oxenham who saw that hearer be becoming moved called through open window for great tankard of sack passed that from hand to hand after horn school boy who have be devouring with eye ear passed have contrived by time to edge into inner ring now stood face to face with hero of emerald crest got a many peep a must at wonder when saw sailor one after having turned over while come forward offer to join mr oxenham soul burned within for nearer view of wondrous horn a magical in effect a of tristrem enchanter in ariosto when group have somewhat broken up oxenham be going into tavern with recruit asked boldly for nearer sight of marvel be granted at once now to astonished gaze displayed city harbor dragon elephant whale fought with shark plate ship of spain island with ape palm tree with name over written here there here be gold again much gold silver inserted most probably a word be in english by hand of mr oxenham lingeringly longingly boy turned round round thought owner of more fortunate than khan kaiser oh if must posse horn what needed on earth beside to make blest say will sell yea marry own soul if can get worth of want horn want soul be somewhat of stale sole for aught know there be plenty of fresh one in bay therewith after much fumbling pulled out tester only one have asked if must buy that twenty of boy thought over what good knight errant must do in such case then answered tell what will fight for thank 'ee sir break jackanapes head for yeo said oxenham call jackanapes again break yours sir boy lifted fist fiercely oxenham looked at minute smilingly tut tut man hit one of own size if will spare little folk like if have boy age sir have man fist will be fifteen year old month know how to answer one who insult fifteen young cockerel look liker twenty said oxenham with admiring glance at lad broad limb keen blue eye curling golden lock round honest face fifteen if have dozen such lad a must make knight of before died eh yeo will do said yeo will make brave gamecock in year two if dare ruffle up so early at tough old hen master like captain at there be general laugh in oxenham joined a loudly a then bade lad tell why be so keen after horn because said looking up boldly want to go to sea want to see indie want to fight spaniard though be gentleman son 'd deal liever be cabin boy on board ship lad having hurried out say fiercely enough dropped head again will cried oxenham with great oath take galloon dine off carbonadoed don whose son be gallant fellow mr leigh of burrough court bless soul know a well a do eddystone kitchen too who sup with to night sir richard grenville dick grenville did not know be in town go home tell father john oxenham will come keep company there off with will make straight with good gentleman will have venture with a for horn let have horn yeo will give noble for not penny noble captain if young master will take poor mariner gift there be for sake of love to calling heaven send luck therein good fellow with impulsive generosity of true sailor thrust horn into boy hand walked away to escape thanks now quoth oxenham merry men make up mind what mannered men be minded to be before take bounty want none of rascally lurching longshore vermin who get five pound out of captain ten out of let sail without after while be stowed away under woman muffler in tavern cellar if man be of humor have better to cut up salt down in barrel for pork before meet again for by light let catch be seven year hence if cut throat upon street be pity if man will be true brother to true brother to will be come wreck prize storm calm salt water fresh victual none share fare alike here hand upon for man so westward ho with rumbelow hurra for spanish main o after oration mr oxenham swaggered into tavern followed by new men boy took way homewards nursing precious horn trembling between hope fear blushing with maidenly shame half sense of wrong doing at having revealed suddenly to stranger darling wish have hidden from father mother ever since be ten year old now young gentleman amyas leigh though come of a good blood a in devon having lived life in what must even now call very best society being on account of valor courtesy truly noble quality showed forth in most eventful life chosen by a hero centre of story be not saving for good look by mean what must be called now day interesting youth still le highly educated one for with exception of little latin have be driven into by repeated blow a if have be nail knew book whatsoever save bible prayer book old mort d'arthur of caxton edition lay in great bay window in hall translation of la casas history of west indie lay beside lately done into english under title of cruelty of spaniard devoutly believed in fairy whom called pixy held that changed baby made mushroom ring on down to dance in when have wart burn went to white witch at northam to charm away thought that sun moved round earth that moon have kindred with cheshire cheese held that swallow slept winter at bottom of horse pond talked like raleigh grenville other low person with broad devonshire accent be in many other respect so very ignorant youth that pert monitor in national school might have have hearty laugh at nevertheless ignorant young savage vacant of glorious gain of nineteenth century child literature science made easy worst of of improved view of english history now current among railway essayist consist in believing person male female before year nearly after to have be hypocrite fool have learnt certain thing must hardly have be taught just now in school in england for training have be that of old persian to speak truth to draw bow of savage virtue have acquired to perfection a well a equally savage one of enduring pain cheerfully of believing to be finest thing in world to be gentleman by word have be taught to understand careful habit of causing needle pain to human being poor rich of taking pride in giving up own pleasure for sake of who be weaker than moreover having be entrusted for last year with breaking of colt care of cast of young hawk father have received from lundy isle have be profiting much by mean of coarse frivolous amusement in perseverance thoughtfulness habit of keeping temper though have never have single object lesson be taught to use intellectual power knew name way of bird fish fly must read a cunningly a oldest sailor meaning of drift of cloud crossed heaven lastly have be for time past on account of extraordinary size strength undisputed cock of school most terrible fighter among bideford boy in brutal habit took much delight contrived strange a may seem to extract from good not only for for others doing justice among school fellow with heavy hand succoring oppressed afflicted so that be terror of sailor lad pride stay of town boy girl hardly considered that have done duty in calling if went home without beating big lad for bullying little one for rest never thought about thinking felt about feeling have ambition whatsoever beyond pleasing father mother getting by honest mean maximum of red quarrenders mazard cherry going to sea when be big enough be what must be now day called by many pious child for though said creed lord prayer night morning went to service at church forenoon read day psalm with mother evening have learnt from from father a proved well in after life that be infinitely noble to do right infinitely base to do wrong yet age of child religious book not having yet dawned on world knew nothing more of theology of own soul than be contained in church catechism be question however on whole whether though grossly ignorant according to modern notion in science religion be altogether untrained in manhood virtue godliness whether barbaric narrowness of information be not somewhat counterbalanced in in rest of generation by depth breadth healthiness of education so let watch up hill a go hugging horn to tell have passed to mother from whom have never hidden anything in life save only that sea fever that only because foreknew that must give pain because moreover being prudent sensible lad knew that be not yet old enough to go that a expressed to afternoon there be use hollaing till be out of wood so go up between rich lane bank heavy with drooping fern honeysuckle out upon windy down toward old court nestled amid ring of wind clipt oak through gray gateway into homeclose then pause moment to look around first at wide bay to westward with southern wall of purple cliff then at dim isle of lundy far away at sea then at cliff down of morte braunton right in front of then at vast yellow sheet of rolling sand hill green alluvial plain dotted with red cattle at foot through silver estuary wind onward toward sea beneath on right torridge like land locked lake sleep broad bright between old park of tapeley charmed rock of hubbastone where seven hundred year ago norse rover landed to lay siege to kenwith castle mile away on left hand not three field away be old stone of bloody corner where retreating dane cut off from ship made last fruitless stand against saxon sheriff valiant men of devon within charmed rock so torridge boatman tell sleep now old norse viking in leaden coffin with fairy treasure crown of gold a boy look at spot fancy almost hope that day may come when will have to do duty against invader a boldly a men of devon did then past far below upon soft southeastern breeze stately ship go sliding out to sea when will sail in see wonder of deep a stand there with beating heart kindling eye cool breeze whistling through long fair curl be symbol though know not of brave young england longing to wing way out of island prison to discover to traffic to colonize to civilize until wind can sweep earth doe not bear echo of english voice patience young amyas thou too shalt forth westward ho beyond thy wildest dream see brave sight do brave deed man have since foundation of world thou too shalt face invader stronger more cruel far than dane norman bear thy part in great titan strife before renown of name of salami will fade away mr oxenham came that evening to supper a have promised a people supped in day in much same manner a do now may drop thread of story for few hour take up again after supper be over come now dick grenville do thou talk good man round will warrant to talk round good wife personage whom oxenham addressed thus familiarly answered by somewhat sarcastic smile mr oxenham give dick grenville with just enough emphasis on mr dick to hint that liberty have be taken with overmuch credit with men mr be credit with fair lady none can doubt friend leigh be heard great ship home yet from strait speaker known well in day a sir richard grenville granville greenvil greenfield with two three other variation be one of truly heroical personage whom providence fitting always men to age work have sent upon earth whereof take right good care not in england only in spain italy in germany netherlands wherever in short great men great deed be needed to lift mediaeval world into modern among heroic face painter of age have preserved none perhaps hardly excepting shakespeare spenser alva farina be more heroic than of richard grenville a stand in prince worthy of devon of spanish type perhaps more truly speaking cornish rather than english with just enough of british element in to give delicacy to massiveness forehead whole brain be of extraordinary loftiness perfectly upright nose long aquiline delicately pointed mouth fringed with short silky beard small ripe yet firm a granite with just pout enough of lower lip to give hint of capacity of noble indignation lay hid under usual courtly calm sweetness if there be defect in face be that eye be somewhat small close together eyebrow though delicately arched without trace of peevishness too closely pressed down upon complexion be dark figure tall graceful altogether likeness of wise gallant gentleman lovely to good men awful to bad men in whose presence none dare say do mean ribald thing whom brave men left feeling nerved to do duty better while coward slipped away a bat before sun so lived moved whether in court of elizabeth giving counsel among wisest in street of bideford capped alike by squire merchant shopkeeper sailor riding along moorland road between house of stow bideford while woman ran out to door to look at great sir richard pride of north devon sitting there in low mullioned window at burrough with cup of malmsey before lute to have just be singing laid across knee while red western sun streamed in upon high bland forehead soft curling lock ever same steadfast god fearing chivalrous man conscious a far a soul so healthy must be conscious of pride of beauty strength valor wisdom race name claimed direct descent from grandfather of conqueror be tracked down century by valiant deed noble benefit to native shire noblest of race men said that be proud must not look round without having something to be proud of that be stern harsh to sailor be only when saw in taint of cowardice falsehood that be subject at moment to such fearful fit of rage that have be seen to snatch glass from table grind to piece in teeth swallow be only when indignation have be aroused by tale of cruelty oppression above by west indian devilry of spaniard whom regarded in day rightly enough a enemy of god man of last fact oxenham be well aware therefore felt somewhat puzzled nettled when after having asked mr leigh leave to take young amyas with set forth in glowing color purpose of voyage found sir richard utterly unwilling to help with suit heyday sir richard be not surely gone over to side of canting fellow spanish jesuit in disguise one of be who pretended to turn up nose at franky drake a pirate be hanged to friend oxenham answered in sententious measured style of day have always held a must know by mr drake booty a well a good friend captain hawkins be lawful prize a being taken from spaniard who be not only hostis humani generis have right to same having robbed violently by torture extreme iniquity from poor indian whom god avenge a surely will amen said mr leigh say amen too quoth oxenham especially if please to avenge by english hand also went on sir richard for rightful owner of said good being miserably dead incapable by reason of servitude of ever recovering share thereof treasure falsely called spanish can not be better bestowed than in building up state of england against natural enemy thereby in building up weal of reformed church throughout world liberty of nation against tyranny more foul rapacious than of nero caligula if be not cause of god for one know not what god cause be a warmed in speech eye flashed very fire hark now said oxenham who can speak more boldly than yet will not help lad to so noble adventure have asked father mother what be answer mine be said mr leigh if be god will that boy must become hereafter such mariner a sir richard grenville let go god be with let first bide here at home be trained if god give grace to become such gentleman a sir richard grenville sir richard bowed low mr leigh catching up last word there mr oxenham can not gainsay that unless will be discourteous to worship for though be weak woman reason yet be mother be only child elder brother be far away god only know whether will see again what be report of virtue learning to compared to sweet presence daily miss ah mr oxenham beautiful joseph be gone though be lord of pharaoh household yet be far away in egypt will take benjamm also ah mr oxenham have child must not ask for mine how do know that sweet madam said adventurer turning first deadly pale then glowing red last word have touched to quick in unexpected place rising courteously laid hand to lip said say more farewell sweet madam god send men such wife a wife said smiling such husband a mine nay will not say that answered with half sneer then farewell friend leigh farewell gallant dick grenville god send see thee lord high admiral when come home yet why must come home will pray for poor jack gentles tut tut man good word said leigh let drink to merry meeting before go rising putting tankard of malmsey to lip passed to sir richard who rose saying to fortune of bold mariner gallant gentleman drank put cup into oxenham hand adventurer face be flushed eye wild whether from liquor have drunk during day whether from mr leigh last speech have not be for few minute lifted cup be in act to pledge when suddenly dropped on table pointed staring trembling up down round room a if following fluttering object there do see bird bird with white breast looked at other leigh who be quick witted man old courtier forced laugh instantly cried nonsense brave jack oxenham leave white bird for men who will show white feather mr leigh wait to pledge oxenham recovered in moment pledged round drinking deep fiercely after hearty farewell departed never hinting again at strange exclamation after be gone while leigh be attending to door mr leigh grenville kept few minute dead silence at last god help said amen said grenville for never needed more indeed madam put faith in such omen sir richard bird have be seen for generation before death of of family know who be at south tawton when mother died brother also saw god help for after be proper man so many lady have thought before now mr leigh well for if have not indeed make account of omen when god be ready for man then must go when can go better said mr leigh who entered have seen especially when be in italy omen prophecy before now beget own fulfilment by driving men into recklessness making run headlong upon very ruin a fancied be running upon said sir richard might have avoided if instead of trusting in know not what dumb dark destiny have trusted in living god by faith in whom men may remove mountain quench fire put to flight army of alien too know know not how know will never die in bed god forfend cried mr leigh why fair madam if die doing duty to god queen thought never move nay to tell truth pray often enough that may be spared misery of imbecile old age that end old northman rightly called ' cow death ' rather than man enough of mr leigh have done wisely to night poor oxenham doe not go on voyage with single eye have talked about with drake hawkins guess why mr leigh touched so home when told that have child have one then in west indie cried good lady god know god grant may not hear of shame sorrow fallen upon ancient honorable house of devon brother stukely be woe enough to north devon for generation poor braggadocio said mr leigh yet not altogether that too for can fight at least so can mastiff boar much more englishman now come hither to adventurous godson look in such doleful dump hear have broken sailor boy head already nearly said young amyas with due modesty be not to go to sea thing in time boy god forbid that worthy parent must keep from noble calling be safeguard of england queen wish to live die master of trawler must like to be brave adventurer like mr oxenham god grant become braver man than for a think to be bold against enemy be common to brute prerogative of man be to be bold against how sir to conquer own fancy amyas own lust ambition in sacred name of duty be to be truly brave truly strong for who can not rule how can rule crew fortune come now will make promise if will bide quietly at home learn from father mother befits gentleman christian a well a seaman day will come when will sail with richard grenville with better men than on nobler errand than gold hunting on spanish main o boy boy said mr leigh hear what good sir richard promise many earl son must be glad to be in place many earl son will be glad to be in place score year hence if will learn what know two can teach now amyas lad will tell for warning history of sir thomas stukely of whom spoke just now who be a men know gallant courtly knight of ancient worshipful family in ilfracombe well practised in war well beloved at first by incomparable queen friend of true virtue a trust will be of yours day who wanted one step to greatness be that in hurry to rule world forgot to rule at first wasted estate in show luxury always intending to be famous destroying own fame while by vainglory haste then to retrieve loss hit upon peopling of florida thou will see done day by god blessing for good friend of mine have errand there a well a did not go about a loyal man to advance honor of queen own honor only dreaming that too must be king be not ashamed to tell majesty that have rather be sovereign of molehill than highest subject of emperor say said mr leigh that told plainly must be prince before died that gave one of pretty quip in return know that majesty have best of fool be many time too strong for wise man by virtue of thick hide for when said that hoped must hear from in new principality sooth ' say graciously enough 'and in what style ' asks 'to dear sister say stukely to clemency have nothing to reply turned away a mr burleigh told laughing ala for said gentle mr leigh such self conceit heaven know have root of in also be very daughter of self will of loud cry out about mine be very bird call for devil broad road lead to death will lead to said sir richard god grant be not upon tower hill for since florida plot after hope of irish preferment came to naught who must not help by fair mean have taken to foul one gone over to italy to pope whose infallibility have not be proof against stukely wit for be soon holiness closet counsellor say bosom friend made give credit to boast that with three thousand soldier must beat english out of ireland make pope son king of ay said mr leigh suppose italian have same fetch now a have when be there to explain such ugly case namely that pope be infallible only in doctrine quoad pope while quoad hominem be even a others indeed in general deal worse so that office not man may be glorified thereby where be stukely now at rome when last heard of ruffling up down vatican a baron ross viscount murrough earl wexford marquis leinster title two more have cost pope little seeing that never be to give plotting say hare brained expedition against ireland by help of spanish king must end in nothing shame ruin now sweet host must call for serving boy lantern home to bed in bideford so amyas leigh went back to school mr oxenham went way to plymouth again sailed for spanish main chapter ii how amyas came home first time si taceant homines facient te sidera notum sol nescit comitis immemor esse sui old epigram on drake five year be past gone be nine of clock on still bright november morning bell of bideford church be still ringing for daily service two hour after usual time instead of going soberly according to wont can not help breaking forth five minute into jocund peal tumbling head over heel in ecstasy of joy bideford street be very flower garden of color swarming with seaman burgher burgher wife daughter in holiday attire garland be hung across street tapestry from window ship in pool be dressed in flag give tumultuous vent to feeling by peal of ordnance of size stable be crammed with horse sir richard grenville house be like very tavern with eating drinking unsaddling running to fro of groom serving men along little churchyard packed full with woman stream gentle blood of north devon tall stately men fair lady worthy of day when gentry of england be by due right leader of people by personal prowess beauty a well a by intellect education first there be lady countess of bath whom sir richard grenville be escorting cap in hand for good earl bourchier be in london with queen there be basset from beautiful umberleigh carys from more beautiful clovelly fortescues of wear fortescues of buckland fortescues from quarter cole from slade stukelys from affton st leger from annery coffin from portledge even coplestones from eggesford thirty mile away last not least for almost stop to give place sir john chichester of ralegh followed in single file after good old patriarchal fashion by eight daughter three of five famous son one to avenge murdered brother be fighting valiantly in ireland hereafter to rule there wisely also a lord deputy baron of belfast meet at gate cousin of arlington behind train of four daughter nineteen son last of whom have not yet passed town hall while first be at lychgate who laughing make way for elder though shorter branch of most fruitful tree so on into church where be placed according to degree at least a near a may be not without few sour look shovings whispering from one high born matron till churchwarden sidesman who never have before so goodly company to arrange have bustled hot red frantic end by imploring abjectly help of great sir richard to tell who everybody be be elder branch be younger who carry eight quartering in arm who only four so prevent setting at deadly feud fine lady of north devon for old men be safe packed away in corporation pew young one care only to get place whence may eye lady at last there be silence looking toward door then distant music flute hautboy drum trumpet come braying screaming thundering merrily up to very church door then cease churchwarden sidesman bustle down to entrance rod in hand there be general whisper rustle not without glad tear blessing from many woman from men also a wonder of day enters rector begin not morning service good old thanksgiving after victory at sea what be have thus sent old bideford wild with goodly joy pious mirth of now only retain tradition in translation of psalm why be eye fixed with greedy admiration on four weather beaten mariner decked out with knot ribbon by loving hand yet more on gigantic figure who walk before beardless boy yet with frame stature of hercules towering like saul of old head shoulder above congregation with golden lock flowing down over shoulder why a five go instinctively up to altar there fall on knee before rail be eye turned to pew where mr leigh of burrough have hid face between hand hood rustle shake to joyful sob because there be fellow feeling of old in merry england in county in town be devon men men of bideford whose name be amyas leigh of burrough john staveley michael heard jonas marwill of bideford thomas braund of clovelly first of english mariner have sailed round world with francis drake be come hither to give god thanks be long story to explain how happened must go back for page two almost to point from whence started in last chapter for somewhat more than twelvemonth after mr oxenham departure young amyas have gone on quietly enough according to promise with exception of certain occasional outburst of fierceness common to young male animal especially to boy of strength of character scholarship indeed progressed better than before home education went on healthily enough be fast becoming young a be right good archer rider swordsman after old school of buckler practice when father having gone down on business to exeter assize caught a be too common in day gaol fever from prisoner sickened in very court died within week now mr leigh be left to god own soul with young lion cub in leash to tame train for life life to come have loved husband fervently holily have be often peevish often melancholy for be disappointed man with estate impoverished by father folly own youthful ambition have led up to court made waste heart purse in following vain shadow be one of men moreover who posse almost gift except gift of power to use though scholar courtier soldier have found when be past forty without settled employment aim in life by reason of certain shyness pride delicate honor call will have always kept from playing winning game in very world after whose prize hankered to last on revenged by continual grumbling at last by good luck met with fair young miss foljambe of derbyshire then about queen elizabeth court who be a tired a of sin of world though have seen le of two contrived to please other so well that though queen grumbled little a usual at lady for marrying at gentleman for adoring one royal self got leave to vanish from little babylon at whitehall settle in peace at burrough in found treasure knew what have found mr leigh be have be from youth one of noble old english churchwomen without superstition without severity who be among fairest feature of heroic time there be certain melancholy about nevertheless for recollection of childhood carried back to time when be awful thing to be protestant must remember among five twenty year ago burning of poor blind joan waste at derby of mistress joyce lewis too like lady born sometimes even now in nightly dream rang in ear mother bitter cry to god to spare fiery torment to give strength to bear a whom loved have borne before for mother who be of good family in yorkshire have be one of queen catherine bedchamber woman bosom friend disciple of anne askew have sat in smithfield with blood curdled by horror to see hapless court beauty month before paragon of henry court carried in chair so crippled be by rack to fiery doom at stake beside fellow courtier mr lascelles while very heaven seemed to shuddering mob around to speak wrath grief in solemn thunder peal heavy drop hissed upon crackling pile therefore sadness hung upon life deepened in day of queen mary when a notorious protestant heretic have have to hide for life among hill cavern of peak be only saved by love husband tenant bore by bold declaration good catholic a be must run through body constable justice priest yea bishop cardinal who dared to serve queen warrant upon wife so escaped a said sadness hung upon life skirt of dark mantle fell upon young girl who have be partner of wandering hiding among lonely hill who after be married gave utterly up to god yet in giving to god mr leigh gave to husband child poor of northam town be none le welcome to grenvilles fortescues chichesters gentle family round who honored husband talent enjoyed wit accustomed to austerity often called forth kindly rebuke of husband yet did so without one superstitious thought of appeasing fancied wrath of god of giving pleasure base thought by pain of hers for spirit have be trained in freest loftiest doctrine of luther school little mystic alt deutsch theologie to great reformer said that owed more than to book save bible st augustine be counsellor comforter by day night now at little past forty be left widow lovely still in face figure still more lovely from divine calm brooded like dove of peace holy spirit of god indeed be over look word gesture sweetness have be ripened by storm a well a by sunshine world have not given must not take away wonder that sir richard lady only that must think act for mother so be that on very day after father funeral when school hour be over instead of coming straight home walked boldly into sir richard grenville house asked to see godfather must be father now sir said firmly sir richard looked at boy broad strong face swore great holy oath like glasgerion by oak ash thorn that must be father to brother to mother for christ sake lady grenville took boy by hand walked home with to burrough there two fair woman fell on other neck wept together one for loss have be other a by prophetic instinct for like loss be to come to also for sweet st leger knew well that husband fiery spirit must never leave body on peaceful bed death a prayed almost nightly that might must find sword in hand upon field of duty of fame there two vowed everlasting sisterhood kept vow after thing went on at burrough a before amyas rode shot boxed wandered on quay at sir richard side for mr leigh be too wise woman to alter one tittle of training husband have thought best for younger boy be enough that elder son have of own accord taken to form of life in in secret heart must fain have moulded child for frank god wedding gift to pure love of hers have won honor at home abroad first at school at bideford then at exeter college where have become friend of sir philip sidney many young man of rank promise next in summer of on way to university of heidelberg have gone to paris with luckily for letter of recommendation to walsingham at english embassy by letter not only fell in second time with philip sidney saved own life a sidney did in massacre of st bartholomew day at heidelberg have stayed two year winning fresh honor from who knew resisting sidney entreaty to follow into italy for scorning to be burden to parent have become at heidelberg tutor to two young german prince whom after living with at father house for year more at last to own great delight took with down to padua to perfect a wrote home according to insufficiency in princely study sidney be now returned to england frank found friend enough without such letter of recommendation diploma did carry from know not how many prince magnifico learned doctor who have fallen in love with learning modesty virtue of fair young englishman ere frank returned to germany have satiated soul with wonder of wondrous land have talked over art of sonneteering with art of history with sarpi have listened between awe incredulity to daring theory of galileo have taken pupil to venice portrait might be painted by paul veronese have seen palace of palladio merchant prince on rialto argosy of ragusa wonder of meeting point of east west have watched tintoretto mighty hand hurling tempestuous glory o'er scene even by dint of private intercession in high place have be admitted to sacred room where with long silver beard undimmed eye amid pantheon of own creation ancient titian patriarch of art still lingered upon earth told old tale of bellini raffaelle michael angelo building of st peter fire at venice sack of rome of king warrior statesman poet long since gone to account showed sacred brush francis first have stooped to pick up for license forbidden to sidney by friend languet have be to rome seen much to scandal of good protestant at home right good fellow a sidney call who have not yet eaten to death pope for time being have seen fresco of vatican heard palestrina preside a chapel master over performance of own music beneath dome of st peter fallen half in love with luscious strain till be awakened from dream by recollection beneath that same dome have gone up thanksgiving to god of heaven for blood stained street shrieking woman heap of insulted corps have beheld in paris on night of st bartholomew at last few month before father died have taken back pupil to home in germany from whence be dismissed a wrote with rich gift then mr leigh heart beat high at thought that wanderer must return ala within month after father death came long letter from frank describing alp valley of waldenses with whose barbes have have much talk about late horrible persecution setting forth how at padua have made acquaintance of illustrious scholar light of age stephanus parmenius commonly called from native place budaeus who have visited geneva with heard disputation of most learned doctor budaeus disliked for hard judgment of god man a much a admired for subtlety being a became italian student platonist of school of ficinus picus mirandolensis so wrote master frank in long sententious letter full of latin quotation letter never reached eye of for whose delight have be penned widow have to weep over alone to weep more bitterly than ever at conclusion in with many excuse frank said that have at special entreaty of said budaeus set out with down danube stream to buda that might before finishing travel make experience of learning for hungarian be famous throughout europe after though wrote again again to father whom fancied living letter in return reached from home for nearly two year till fearing mishap hurried back to england to find mother widow brother amyas gone to south sea with captain drake of plymouth yet even then after year of absence be not allowed to remain at home for sir richard to whom idleness be thing horrible unrighteous must have up doing again before six month be over sent off to court to lord hunsdon there being a delicately beautiful a brother be huge strong have speedily by carew interest that of sidney uncle leicester found entrance into office in queen of old schoolmaster secondly because of young beauty will take in order explain vindex brimblecombe whilom servitor of exeter college oxford commonly called sir vindex after fashion of time be in day master of grammar school of bideford be at root godly kind hearted pedant enough like most schoolmaster in old flogging day have heart pretty well hardened by long baneful license to inflict pain at will on weaker than power healthful enough for victim for doubtless flogging be best of punishment being not only shortest also mere bodily animal not like most of new fangled humane punishment spiritual fiendish torture for executioner pretty certain to eradicate from noblest spirit trace of chivalry tenderness for weak a well often a self control command of temper be that a may old sir vindex have heart enough to feel that be now duty to take especial care of fatherless boy to whom tried to teach qui quae quod only outcome of new sense of responsibility be rapid increase in number of flogging rose from about two week to one per diem not without consequence to pedagogue for while amyas have never for moment lost sight of darling desire for sea life when must not wander on quay spake lady bath whom sir richard wisely answered not for be terribly learned member of college of critic disputed even with sidney sister chieftaincy of euphuists so sir richard answered not answer be made for since whole choir of mus madam have migrated to court of whitehall wonder if dew of parnassus must fertilize at time even devon moor speaker be tall slim young man five twenty year old of so rare delicate beauty that seemed that greek statue rather one of pensive pious knight whom old german artist took delight to paint have condescended to tread awhile work day earth in living flesh blood forehead be very lofty smooth eyebrow thin greatly arched envious gallant whispered that something at least of curve be due to art a be also exceeding smoothness of delicate cheek face be somewhat long thin nose aquiline languid mouth showed perhaps too much of ivory upper teeth most striking point of speaker appearance be extraordinary brilliancy of complexion shamed with whiteness that of fair lady round save where open on cheek bright red spot gave warning a did long thin neck taper hand of sad possibility perhaps not far off possibility saw with inward sigh except whose doting glance a well a resemblance to fair youth proclaimed at once mother mr leigh master frank for be be dressed in very extravagance of fashion not so much from vanity a from that delicate instinct of self respect must keep men spruce spotless from one year end to upon desert island for a frank used to say in sententious way mr frank leigh at least beholds though none else be by why must be more discourteous to than permit others to be be sure that who be grobian in own company will sooner later become grobian in of friend so mr frank be arrayed spotlessly after latest fashion of milan not in trunk hose slashed sleeve in french standing collar treble quadruple daedalian ruff stiff necked rabato have more arch for pride propped up with wire timber than five london bridge in close fitting perfectly plain suit of dove color set off cunningly delicate proportion of figure delicate hue of complexion be shaded from sun by broad dove colored spanish hat with feather to match looped up over right ear with pearl brooch therein crowned e supposed by damsel of bideford to stand for elizabeth be whispered to be gift of most illustrious hand same looping up be not without good reason purpose prepense thereby world have full view of beautiful little ear looked a if have be cut of cameo made a lady rich once told to hearken only to music of sphere to chant of cherub behind said ear be stuck fresh rose golden hair be drawn smoothly back round to left temple whence tied with pink ribbon in great true lover knot mighty love lock curled a have be laid in press rolled down low upon bosom oh frank frank have come out on purpose to break heart of bideford burgher daughter if so did expect to further that triumph by dyeing that pretty little pointed beard with shame report of bright vermilion know better frank so doe mother be masquerading angel after in spite of knot perfume gold chain round neck german princess gave emerald ring on right fore finger hatton gave pair of perfumed with than ever for a be way with sailor who after be truest lover a be finest fellow god bless upon earth lonely ship watch have be spent in imprinting on imagination month after month year after year where have seen last amyas be recalling to look gesture of lost adventurer wondering at for so doing till retired to sleep only to renew fancy in dream at last found knew not how sailing westward ever up wake of setting sun in chase of tiny sail be john oxenham upon be painful sense unless came up with in time something fearful must come to pas ship must not sail around floated sargasso bed clogging bow with long snaky coil of weed still tried to sail tried to fancy that be sailing till sun went down be utter dark then moon arose in moment john oxenham ship be close aboard sail be torn fluttering pitch be streaming from side bulwark be rotting to decay be line of dark object dangling along mainyard line of hanged men horror of horror from yard arm close above john be corpse looked down with grave light eye beckoned pointed a if to show way strove to speak must not pointed still not forward back along course when amyas looked back behold behind be snow range of andes glittering in moon knew that be in south sea once more that america be between home still corpse kept pointing back back looking at with yearning eye of agony lip longed to tell awful secret till sprang up woke with shout of terror found lying in little coved chamber in dear old burrough with gray autumn morning already stealing in feverish excited tried in vain to sleep again after hour tossing rose dressed started for bathe on beloved old pebble ridge a passed mother door must not help looking in dim light of morning showed bed pillow have not be pressed that night mother in long white night dress be kneeling at other end of chamber at prie dieu absorbed in devotion gently slipped in without word knelt down at side turned smiled passed arm around went on silently with prayer why not be for knew prayed also prayer be for for poor lost john oxenham vanished crew at last rose standing above parted yellow lock from off brow looked long lovingly into face there be nothing to be spoken for there be nothing to be concealed between two soul a clear a glass knew other meant knew that own thought be known at last mutual gaze be over stooped kissed on brow be in act to turn away a tear dropped on forehead little bare foot be peeping out from under dress bent down kissed again again then looking up a if to excuse have such pretty foot mother instantly with woman instinct have hidden have be beauty once a said though hair be gray rose have faded long ago be beautiful still in eye saw deeper than mere outward red white dear father used to say so thirty year ago say so still always be beautiful be beautiful now what be to silly boy will play lover with old mother go take walk think of younger lady if can find worthy of so son went forth mother returned to prayer walked down to pebble ridge where surge of bay have defeated own fury by rolling up in course of age rampart of gray boulder stone two mile long a cunningly curved smoothed fitted a if work have be done by human hand protects from high tide of spring autumn fertile sheet of smooth alluvial turf sniffing keen salt air like young sea dog stripped plunged into breaker dived rolled tossed about foam with stalwart arm till heard hailed from off shore looking up saw standing on top of rampart tall figure of cousin eustace amyas be half disappointed at coming for love lorn rascal have be dreaming way thither of rose salterne have wish for companion who must prevent dreaming of way back nevertheless not having seen eustace for three year be civil to scramble out dress while cousin walked up down upon turf inside eustace leigh be son of younger brother of leigh of burrough who have more le cut off from family indeed from countryman by remaining papist true though born papist have not always be one for like many of gentry have become protestant under edward sixth then papist again under mary to honor be said at point have stopped having too much honesty to turn protestant second time a hundred did at elizabeth accession so papist remained living out of way of world in great rambling dark house still called chapel on atlantic cliff in moorwinstow parish not far from sir richard grenville house of penal law never troubled for in first place never troubled one who did not make conspiracy rebellion integral doctrine of religious creed next seldom troubled even unless fired with glory of martyrdom bullied long suffering of elizabeth council into giving desert like poor father southwell in after year insisted on being hanged whether burleigh liked not moreover in man land end of earth be that old house at moorwinstow that dozen conspiracy might have be hatched there without one hearing of jesuit seminary priest skulked in out year round unquestioned though unblest found sort of piquant pleasure like naughty boy who have crept into store closet in living in mysterious little den in lonely turret going up through trap door to celebrate mass in secret chamber in roof where be allowed by power be to play a much a chose at persecuted saint preach about hiding in den cave of earth for once when zealous parson of moorwinstow having discovered what everybody knew already existence of mass priest idolatry at chapel house made formal complaint thereof to sir richard called on a nearest justice of peace to put in force act of fourteenth of elizabeth that worthy knight only rated soundly for fantastical puritan bade mind own business if wished not to make place too hot for whereon for temporal authority happily for peace of england kept in day somewhat tight hand upon spiritual one worthy parson subsided for after mr thomas leigh paid tithe regularly enough be content a expressed to bow head in house of rimmon like naaman of old by eating mr leigh dinner a often a be invited ignoring vocation of old father francis who sat opposite to dressed a layman calling young gentleman pedagogue said bird of ill omen have very considerable lien on conscience of superstitious men always have be now tall handsome light complexioned man with huge upright forehead very small mouth dry set expression of face be always trying to get free rather to seem free what strange cattle have be importing now look at three legged fellow trying to get aloft on wrong side how claw at horse rib like cat scratching elder stem three legged man be tall meek looking said ostler who came last night in pinnace from milford haven name mr morgan evans mr evan morgan mr juda iscariot mr iscariot juda said amyas between teeth then observed aloud that welsh gentleman gentleman hereabout like worship whom god preserve send virtuous lady one worthy of thou hast villainously glib tongue fellow said amyas who be thoroughly out of humor sneaking down visage too when come to look at doubt be papist too do well sir what if be trust break queen law by if attend northam church pay month shilling for use of poor a act directs beyond man dare demand of dare act directs face if see again there be harm in said frank glad think so quarrel with amyas first day quarrel with thee darling old fellow have sooner kiss dust off thy foot if be worthy of so now away home inside there eustace leigh pulled up short groom leaping from horse knelt down humbly in wet grass implored blessing of two valiant gentleman of wale who having graciously bestowed with three finger apiece became thenceforth no longer morgan evans evan morgan welshman gentleman father parson father gampian jesuit gentleman in sense in word be applied in book after few minute party be again in motion must have after sitting with head in hand for hour more arose suddenly started off along cliff towards marsland must go see lucy passmore white witch lucy knew everything lucy must tell what to do perhaps even whom to marry lucy be fat jolly woman of fifty with little pig eye twinkled like spark of fire eyebrow sloped upwards outwards like of satyr a if have be a indeed have life looking out of corner of eye qualification a white witch be boundless cunning equally boundless good nature considerable knowledge of human weakness mesmeric power skill in yarbs a called simple firm faith in virtue of own incantation faculty of holding tongue by dint of contrived to gain fair share of money also liked even better of power among simple folk for many mile round if child be scalded tooth ached piece of silver be stolen heifer shrew struck pig bewitched young damsel crost in love lucy be called in lucy found remedy especially for latter complaint now then found on ticklish ground for kind heartedness compelled to help distressed damsel out of scrape sometimes compelled also to help into one whereon enraged father called lucy ugly name threatened to send into exeter gaol for witch smiled quietly hinted that if be like be ready to return evil for evil such talk a must bring blessing on that spoke being translated into plain english meant if trouble will overlook e fascinate then pig will die horse stray cream turn sour barn be fired son have st vitus dance daughter fit so on woe on woe till be very probably starved to death in ditch by virtue of terrible little eye of mine at in spite of swearing bullying know be now shaking in shoe for fear so have much better hold tongue give drink of cider leave ill alone lest make worse not that lucy ever proceeded to such fearful extremity on contrary boast belief too be that be sent into world to make poor soul a happy a must by lawful mean of course if possible if not why unlawful one be better than none for must bear to see poor creature taking on be too too tender hearted so be to one husband tall simple hearted rabbit faced man good deal older than fully agreeing with sir richard grenville great axiom that who can not obey can not rule lucy have be for last five twenty year training pretty smartly to obey with intention be to be charitably hoped of letting rule in turn when lesson be perfected bore honor however meekly enough having boundless respect for wife wisdom firm belief in supernatural power let go own way earn own money while got little more in truly pastoral method not extinct yet along lonely cliff by feeding herd of dozen donkey twenty goat donkey fetched at low tide white shell sand be to be sold for manure to neighboring farmer goat furnished milk kiddy pie when there be milking sand carrying to be done old will passmore just sat under sunny rock watched buck goat rattle horn together thinking about nothing at taking very good care while to inquire to see who came in out of little cottage in glen prophetess when rose approached oracular cave be seated on tripod in front of fire distilling strong water out of penny royal sooner did distinguished visitor appear at hatch than still be left to take care of clean apron mutch having be slipt on lucy welcomed rose with endless courtesy bless dear soul alive who ever must have thought to see rose of torridge to poor little place rose sat down then how to begin be more than knew stayed silent full five minute looking earnestly at point of shoe till lucy who be adept in such case thought best to proceed to business at once save rose shook head ah well went on in half bantering tone not so asy be then one gude for one thing one for eh one have blood money so cunning woman a truly be talking half to herself ran over name thought must say if have seen in adventure how longed to have have with to show glorious sight till frank let have own way then out came whole story of simple fellow daily hourly devotion to through three long year of world wide wandering oh frank must hardly think of anything in church other day god forgive did seem so hard for to be only face did not see have not seen yet so thought dear lad said that be being delicious enough be a pretty a ever ten time a pretty dear lad a young fellow round have discovered if mean to win wear god grant may fare worse will have rival enough to get rid of liege fear of frank be swash buckler thank god if one get in way will serve a mastiff did terrier just drop over quay into river to cool name not amyas giant swung laughing out of room slept night like seal not without dream of course of rose salterne next morning according to wont went into mother room whom be sure to find up at prayer for liked to say prayer too by side a used to do when be little boy seemed so homelike said after three year knocking up down in man land coming gently to door for fear of disturbing entering unperceived beheld sight stopped short mr leigh be sitting in chair with face bowed fondly down upon head of brother frank who knelt before face buried in lap amyas must see that whole form be quivering with stifled emotion mother be just finishing last word of well known text for sake gospel will receive hundred fold in present life father mother brother sister not wife interrupted frank with voice stifled with sob be too precious gift for even to promise to who gave up first love for sake yet said after moment silence have not heaped with blessing enough already that must repine rage at refusing one more even though one be mother be son god will know even though amyas never doe looked up with clear blue eye white forehead face be a face of angel of saw that amyas be present started blushed mother motioned away with eye went quietly out a one merely a scholar a gentleman one who have fought ere now to whom have happened mr cary to kill man on whose soul may god have mercy be pride to remember have never yet fought in own quarrel trust in god that never will for a there be nothing more noble blessed than to fight in behalf of whom love so to fight in own private behalf be thing not to be allowed to christian man unless refusal import utter loss of life honor even then may be though must not lay burden on man conscience be better not to resist evil to overcome with good can tell will said amyas be not troubled with fear of ghost off lima nothing about poor stukely that last be popish prayer master frank said old mr cary most worshipful sir surely must not wish god not to have mercy on soul eh of course not be settled by now for be dead poor fellow certainly dear sir can not help being little fond of still eh why must be brute if be not be schoolfellow though be somewhat younger many good thrashing have given one can not will be enough enough be big enough brave enough for ten still more merrier fewer better fare if might ask first last favor worshipful sir said frank very earnestly must grant two thing that must let none go to freshwater brother that whatsoever will bring back will be kept a secret a commonweal loyalty will permit trust that be not so unknown to to others that can doubt for moment that whatsoever may do will satisfy at once honor own dear young gentleman there be need of so many courtier word be father friend yours god forbid that cary for guess drift must ever wish to make head heart ache be more than of whom be written 'though thou bray fool in mortar yet will not folly depart from ' interposed frank in so sad tone one at table replied few more word be exchanged till two brother be safe outside house then amyas said frank be devon man handiwork nevertheless be eustace handwriting impossible lad have be secretary to prince learnt to interpret cipher to watch pen stroke young a be think that be not easily deceived must god be come on lad strike man hastily lest thou cut off thine own flesh so forth two went along park to eastward past head of little wood embosomed fishing town steep stair of house clinging to cliff far below bright slate roof white wall glittering in moonlight on half mile farther along steep hill side fenced with oak wood down to water edge by narrow forest path to point where two glen meet pour streamlet over cascade hundred foot in height into sea below by side of waterfall narrow path climb upward from beach here be that two brother expected to meet messenger frank insisted on taking station below amyas said that be certain that eustace must make appearance that be more fit than amyas to bring to reason by parley that if amyas must keep watch twenty yard above escape of messenger must be impossible moreover be elder brother post of honor be right so amyas obeyed after making promise that if more than one man came up path must let pas before challenged so that might bring to bay at same time so amyas took station under high marl bank bedded in luxuriant crown fern kept eye steadily on frank who sat down on little knoll of rock where be now garden on cliff edge part path dark chasm down stream rush to final leap over cliff there amyas sat full half hour glanced at while from frank to look upon scene around outside southwest wind blew fresh strong moonlight danced upon thousand crest of foam within black jagged point sheltered town sea did heave in long oily swell of rolling silver onward into black shadow of hill within town pier lay invisible save where twinkling light gave token of lonely fisher wife watching weary night through for boat must return with dawn here there upon sea black speck marked herring boat drifting with line of net right off mouth of glen amyas saw with beating heart large two masted vessel lying to must be portugal eagerly looked up glen listened heard nothing sweeping of wind across down five hundred foot above sough of waterfall upon rock below saw nothing vast black sheet of oak wood sloping up to narrow blue sky above broad bright hunter moon woodcock chuckling to other hawked to fro like swallow between tree top sky at last heard rustle of fallen leaf shrank closer closer into darkness of bank then swift light step not down path from above upward from below heart beat quick loud in half minute man came in sight within three yard of frank hiding place frank sprang out instantly amyas saw bright blade glance in clear october moonlight stand in queen name man drew pistol from under cloak fired full in face have happened in day of detonator frank chance have be small to get ponderous wheel lock under weigh be longer business before fizzing of flint have ceased frank have struck up pistol with rapier exploded harmlessly over head man instantly dashed weapon in face closed blow luckily did not take effect on delicate forehead struck on shoulder nevertheless frank who with grace agility be a fragile a lily very bubble of earth staggered lost guard before must recover amyas saw dagger gleam one two three blow fiercely repeated mad with fury be with in instant be scuffling together so closely in shade that be afraid to use sword point with hilt dealt single blow full on ruffian cheek be enough with hideous shriek fellow rolled over at foot amyas set foot on in act to run through stop stay almost screamed frank be eustace cousin eustace leant against tree amyas sprang towards frank waved off be nothing scratch have paper be sure of take for god sake let go villain give paper cried amyas setting foot once more on writhing eustace whose jaw be broken across struck foully from behind moaned vanity envy even then coming out in faint foolish attempt to prove amyas not so very much better man hound do think dare not strike in front give paper letter popish devilry carry a live will cut off head take even if cost shame of stripping corpse give up traitor murderer give say setting foot on afresh raised sword eustace be usually craven be cowed between agony shame have heart to resist martyrdom looked so splendid when consummated selon le regles on tower hill tyburn before pitying still better scoffing multitude looked confused dirty ugly business there in dark forest a lay stream of moonlight bathed mighty cousin broad clear forehead long golden lock white terrible blade till seemed to eustace superstitious eye like one of fair young st michael trampling on fiend have seen abroad in old german picture shuddered pulled packet from bosom threw from murmuring have not given swear to that be paper have in cipher out of cipher swear on soul die eustace swore tell who be accomplice never said eustace cruel have not degraded enough already wretched young man burst into tear hid bleeding face in hand one hint of honor made amyas a gentle a lamb lifted eustace up bade run for life be to owe life then to not in least only to being leigh go will be worse for eustace went while amyas catching up precious packet hurried to frank have fainted already brother have to carry a far a park before must find of other watcher blind a far a be concerned be complete have heard seen nothing whosoever have brought packet have landed knew not where so all returned to court carrying frank who recovered gradually having rather bruise than wound for foe have struck wildly with trembling hand hour after amyas mr cary son will be in deep consultation over following epistle only paper in packet be not in cipher 'dear brother n s in chto et ecclesia be to inform friend of cause s josephus have landed in smerwick with eight hundred valiant crusader burning with holy zeal to imitate last year martyr of carrigfolium to expiate offence fear may have be many by propagation of most holy faith have purified fort be strenuously rebuilding with prayer holy water from stain of heretical footstep consecrated afresh to service of heaven a first fruit of isle of saint having displayed consecrated banner to adoration of faithful have returned to earl desmond may establish faith weak a yet by reason of allurement of world though since by valor effectual be opened there be many adversary be swift for so do poor lamb of church tremble at fury of heretic that hundred will flee before one englishman indeed be not for divine charity toward church cover multitude of sin with be resplendent neither country must be by carnal judgment counted worthy of so great labor in behalf for be given much to lying theft drunkenness vain babbling profane dancing singing be still a s gildas report of beore careful to shroud villainous face in bushy hair than decently to cover body while land by reason of tyranny of chieftain continual war plundering among tribe leave weak divided easy prey to myrmidon of excommunicate usurping englishwoman lie utterly waste with fire defaced with corps of starved slain be thing while holy virtue of catholic obedience still flourish in heart church care not for conservation of body good of immortal soul if devout lady will so will may obtain from liberality shirt for worthless tabernacle also
