ensuing chapter chapter vii true tragical history of mr john oxenham of plymouth fair breeze blew white foam flew furrow follow 'd free be first that ever burst into silent sea ancient mariner be too late too dark last night to see old house at stow will look round then bright october day while sir richard amyas about eleven o'clock in forenoon be pacing up down terraced garden to south amyas have slept till luncheon e till hour ago sir richard in spite of bustle of last night be up in valley by six o'clock recreating valiant soul of two terrier dog by chase of sundry badger old stow house stand rather stood four mile beyond cornish border on northern slope of largest loveliest of combes of spoke in last chapter eighty year after sir richard time there arose there huge palladian pile bedizened with monstrosity of bad taste be built so story run by charles second for sir richard great grandson heir of famous sir bevil who defeated parliamentary troop at stratton died soon after fighting valiantly at lansdowne over bath like most other thing owed existence to stuart rose only to fall again old man who have seen a boy foundation of new house laid lived to see pulled down again very brick timber sold upon spot since then stable have become farm house tennis court sheep cote great quadrangle rick yard civilization spreading wave on wave so fast elsewhere have surged back from lonely corner of land let hope only for while be not writing of great new stow house of past glory whereof quaint picture still hang in neighboring house of famed sir bevil most beautiful gallant of generation on whom with grandfather sir richard old prince have pompous epigram where next will famous grenvil ash stand thy grandsire fill sea thou land have to deal with simpler age sterner generation with old house have stood there in part at least from gray mythic age when first sir richard son of hamon dentatus lord of carboyle grandson of duke robert son of rou settled at bideford after slaying prince of south galis lord of glamorgan gave to cistercian monk of neath conquest in south wale be huge rambling building half castle half dwelling house such a may be seen still almost unique specimen in compton castle near torquay dwelling place of humphrey gilbert walter raleigh half brother richard grenville bosom friend of whom more hereafter on three side to north west south lofty wall of old ballium still stood with machicolated turret loophole dark downward cranny for dropping stone fire on besieger relic of more unsettled age southern court of ballium have become flower garden with quaint terrace statue knot of flower clipped yew holly pedantry of topiarian art toward east where vista of valley opened old wall be gone frowning norman keep ruined in war of rose have be replaced by rich stately architecture of tudor altogether house like time be in transitionary state represented faithfully enough passage of old middle age into new life have just burst into blossom throughout europe never let pray to see autumn winter from house on three side hill sloped steeply down garden where sir richard amyas be walking gave truly english prospect at one turn must catch over western wall glimpse of blue ocean flecked with passing sail at next spread far below range on range of fertile park stately avenue yellow autumn woodland purple heather moor lapping over over other up valley to old british earthwork stood black furze grown on conical peak standing out against sky on highest bank of hill closed valley to east lofty tower of kilkhampton church rich with monument offering of five century of grenvilles yellow eastern haze hung soft over park wood moor red cattle lowed to other a stood brushing away fly in rivulet far below colt in horse park close on right whinnied a played together sire from queen park on opposite hill answered in fuller though fainter voice rutting stag made still woodland rattle with hoarse thunder rival far up valley gave back trumpet note of defiance be defied from heathery brow quivered far away above half seen through veil of eastern mist close at home upon terrace before house amid romping spaniel golden haired child sat lady grenville beautiful st leger of annery central jewel of glorious place looked down at noble child then up at more noble husband round at broad paradise of west till life seemed too full of happiness heaven of light while up down paced amyas sir richard talking long earnestly slow for knew that turning point of boy life be come yes said sir richard after amyas in blunt simple way have told whole story about rose salterne brother yes sweet lad thou hast chosen better part thou thy brother also will not be taken from only be strong lad trust in god that will make man of do trust said amyas thank god said sir richard that have taken from heart that be great anxiety for from day that good father who sleep in peace committed to hand for best thing amyas become when misused very worst love of woman because be able to lift man soul to heaven be also able to drag down to hell have learnt better amyas know with old german forefather that a tacitus saith serum juvenum venus ideoque inexhausta pubertas not only that amyas trust that silly fashion of french italian to be hanging ever at woman apron string so that boy will count man unless can vagghezziare le donne whether maid wife ala matter little that fashion say be little le hurtful to soul than open sin for by be bred vanity expense envy heart burning yea hatred murder often even if be escaped yet rich treasure of manly worship must be kept for one alone be squandered parted upon many bride at last come in for nothing very last leaving caput mortuum of bridegroom heart becomes mere ornament for table mean whereby may obtain progeny may god who have saved from death in life save also a spoke looked down toward wife upon terrace below a if guessing instinctively that be talking of looked up with so sweet smile sir richard stern face melted into very glory of spiritual sunshine amyas looked at sighed then turning conversation suddenly may go to ireland to morrow will sail in beary for milford haven with letter to winter if wind serf may bid master drop down river tonight be off for must lose time winter said amyas be friend of mine since left drake so cowardly at strait of magellan duty must not wait for private quarrel even though be just one lad will not be general when come to marshal lord deputy give of letter will set work hard work too warrant want nothing better right lad best reward for having wrought well already be to have more to do have be faithful over few thing must find account in being made ruler over many thing be true heroical rest only be worthy of gentleman son of god a for who either in world world to come look for idleness hope that god will feed with pleasant thing a be with spoon amyas count coward base even though call saint elect wish must persuade poor cousin of have yet to learn what losing life to save mean amyas bad men have taught fear anabaptist puritan at home teach little else that be one great business of one to save own soul after dy one for that not divine self sacrifice be one thing needful better part mary chose think men be inclined enough already to be selfish without being taught that right lad for if must hang up teacher on high a enemy of mankind corrupter of youth must do gladly be there not cowardice self seeking enough about heart of fallen son of adam that false prophet with bait of heaven terror of hell must exalt dirtiest vice into heavenly virtue mean of bliss farewell to chivalry to desperate valor farewell to patriotism loyalty farewell to england to manhood of england if once will become fashion of preacher to bid man a jesuit do take care first of what call safety of soul man will be afraid to die at post because will be afraid that be not fit to die amyas do thou do thy duty like man to thy country thy queen thy god count thy life worthless thing a did holy men of old do thy work lad leave thy soul to care of who be just merciful in that reward man according to work be there respect of person with god now come in take letter to horse if hear of thee dead there at smerwick fort with thy wound in front will weep for thy mother lad will have never sigh for thee if one will be startled at hearing fine gentleman warrior like sir richard quote scripture think scripture also must be referred to writing of time may read not without profit to if discover therefrom how be possible then for men of world to be thoroughly ingrained with gospel yet to be free from taint of superstitious fear false devoutness religion of day be such a soldier need have be ashamed of confessing at least sir richard died a lived without shudder without whine be last word fifteen year after a lay shot through through captive among popish spaniard priest crucifix confession extreme unction other mean appliance for delivering men out of hand of god of love here die richard grenville with joyful quiet mind for have ended life a true soldier ought fighting for country queen religion honor soul willingly departing from body leaving behind lasting fame of having behaved a valiant soldier be in duty bound to do be last word of richard grenville pulpit of day have taught to to return day event be not over yet for when went down into house first person whom met be old steward in search of master there be manner of roog sir richard masterless man at door very forward fellow must need speak of rack already strappado too to care much what man can do unto must heartily that thought lawful to be sworn not so thinking can submit to cruelty of man though did expect more merciful thing a most leave island took good store of pearl feeding sumptuously on wild cattle hog until tenth day when there came by small bark took found from quito on board pezos of gold other store with if have be greater richer must make prince of bark came in sight on sixteenth day be taken without shot slaughter taking of bark verily believe be ruin of mother son of being asked why answered first because of discontent be bred thereby for on board be found no gold only pezos of silver sir richard grenville thou greedy fellow be not that enough to stay stomach yeo answered that must to god have be that moreover weight of silver be afterwards hindrance to fresh cause of discontent a must afterwards declare so that have be well for sir if have left behind a mr drake left three year before carried away gold only in do see evident hand of god just punishment for greediness of gain who caused mr oxenham by whom have hoped to attain great wealth to be snare to cause of utter ruin do think then said sir richard mr oxenham deceived wilfully will never believe that sir mr oxenham have private reason for waiting for ship for sake of one on board whose face must that have never seen though saw then a fear not for first time by many one so be silent come said hearer have brought thus far must go on gentleman have concealed matter from men on voyage home since hope will be secret in matter for honor of noble captain comfort of friend who be alive for think shame to publish harm of gallant gentleman of ancient worshipful family to true kind captain when what be done can not be undone least said ours for a must out in bark of lima took young lady a fair a sunshine sir seemingly about two three twenty year of age having with tall young lad of sixteen little girl marvellously pretty child of about six seven lady herself be of excellent beauty like whale tooth for whiteness so that crew wondered at must not be satisfied with looking upon gentleman be strange that lady seemed in wise afraid mournful bid little girl fear naught a did also mr oxenham lad kept very sour countenance more when saw lady mr oxenham speaking together apart well sir after good luck be minded to have gone straight of lady for a be about to go ashore going down into cabin of prize saw mr oxenham that lady making great cheer of other with bey life bey king ' 'light of eye such toy being bidden by mr oxenham to thrust upon deck going below again told mr oxenham what thought said that be better to put dagger into at once professing to be ready so to do for grievous sin seeing that be committed in unregenerate finding few pearl being wearied with watching warding so many spaniard negro came clamoring to swore that must return leave there with lady so all went on board pinnace again one in ill humor with captain with well sir came back to mouth of river there began trouble for negro a soon a be on shore called on mr oxenham to fulfil bargain have made with now came out what few of knew till then that have agreed with cimaroons that must have prisoner be taken save gold though loath be about to give up spaniard to near forty in supposing that intended to use a slave a stood talking one of spaniard understanding what be forward threw on knee before mr oxenham shrieking like madman entreated not to be given up into hand of 'those devil said 'who never take spanish prisoner roast alive then eat heart among ' asked negro if be possible to answered what be to others said boldly that be true enough that revenge made best sauce nothing be so sweet a spanish blood one pointing to lady said such foul devilish thing a must be ashamed for to speak to hear at be like men amazed for very horror mr oxenham said 'you incarnate fiend if have taken fellow for slave have be fair enough for be once slave to doubt not cruelly used enough a for abomination say 'god do so to more also if let one of come into murderous hand so there be great quarrel mr oxenham stoutly bade put prisoner on board ship again so let prize go taking with only treasure lady little maid so lad went on to panama god wrath having gone out against well sir cimaroons after went away from swearing revenge for cared little enough rowed up river to place where three stream met then up least of three four day journey till grew shoal swift there hauled pinnace upon sand mr oxenham asked men whether be willing to carry gold silver over mountain to north sea of at first be loath to do others advised that must leave plate behind take gold only for must have cost three four journey at least mr oxenham promised man pezos of silver over above wage made content enough be to start morrow morning sir night a god have ordained came mishap by rash speech of mr oxenham threw abroad again for when have carried treasure about league inland hidden away in house made of bough mr o being always full of fair lady spoke to william penberthy of marazion good comrade few more saying 'that have need to return to england seeing that be already in very garden of eden wanted for nothing must live without labor toil that be better when got over to north sea to go seek out fair island there dwell in joy pleasure till life end two ' said 'will be king queen whom can trust officer for servant will have indian who warrant will be more fain to serve honest merry master like than spanish devil much more of like word liked well mind ala being given altogether to carnal pleasure vanity a did william penberthy good comrade on whom trust god have have mercy rest sir took matter across began murmuring against captain saying that poor honest mariner like have always labor pain while took delight with lady that must have at least one merry night before be slain by cimaroons eaten by panther lagartos so got out of pinnace two great skin of canary wine be taken in lima prize sat down to drink moreover there be in pinnace great sight of hen came from same prize by mr o set great store keeping for lady little maid falling upon men began to blaspheme saying 'what plague have captain to fill boat with dirty live lumber for giglet sake have better right to good supper than ever have might fast awhile to cool hot blood so cooked ate hen plucking on board pinnace letting feather fall into stream when william penberthy good comrade saw feather floating away down asked if be mad to lay trail by spaniard must surely track out if came after a without doubt must laughed to scorn said that spanish cur dared follow on heel of true english mastiff a be other boastful speech at last being heated with wine began afresh to murmur at captain one speaking of counsel about island rest altogether took amiss out of way sprang up cry treason others that meant to defraud of plate have promised others that meant to desert in strange land so forth till mr o hearing hubbub came out to from house when reviled foully swearing that meant to cheat one edward stile wapping man mad with drink dared to say that be fool for not giving up prisoner to negro what be to if lady roasted negro must have yet drawing sword ran upon captain for be about to strike through body captain not caring to waste steel on ribald with fist caught buffet behind ear that fell down stark dead rest stood amazed then mr oxenham called out 'all honest men who know can trust stand by lawful captain against ruffian whereon sir penberthy good comrade four plymouth men who have sailed with mr o in mr drake ship knew trusty valiant condition came over to swore before god to stand by lady then said mr o to rest carry treasure knave will not give answer here refused unless must before started give man share so mr o waxed very mad swore that must never be served by men who did not trust so went in again that night be spent in great disquiet five others keeping watch about house of bough till rest fell asleep in drink next morning when wine be gone out of mr o asked whether must go to hill with find negro persuade after to carry treasure to agreed after awhile thinking so must save labor went off with mr oxenham leaving six who have stood by to watch lady treasure after have taken oath of that must deal justly obediently by by god know gentleman did so parted with much weeping wailing of lady be gone seven day time kept that lady faithfully honestly bringing best must find serving upon bended knee for admirable beauty for excellent condition for be certainly of noble kin courteous without fear a if have be very princess kept always within house little maid god bless did not soon learned to play with with so that made great cheer of gentleman sailor fashion for know must always have minion aboard to pet amuse maybe monkey little dog singing bird ay mouse spider if have nothing better to play withal be wonderful sharp sir be little maid picked up english from fast calling jolly mariner doubt have forgotten by now hope in god be not so therewith good fellow began wiping eye well sir on seventh day six be down by pinnace clearing out little maid with gathering of flower william penberthy fishing on bank about hundred yard below when on sudden leap up run toward cry 'here come hen feather back again with vengeance so bade catch up little maid run for house for spaniard be upon be too true for before must win house there be full eighty shot at heel must not overtake nevertheless of stopping fixed calivers let fly killing one of plymouth men rest of escaped to house catching up lady fled forth not knowing whither went while spaniard finding house treasure pursued farther for day next wandered in great misery lady weeping continually calling for mr oxenham most piteously little maid likewise till with much ado found track of comrade went up that a best might at nightfall by good hap met whole crew coming back with negro more with bow arrow at sight be great joy embracing be strange thing sir to see lady for before be altogether desperate yet be now very lioness a soon a have got love again prayed earnestly not to care for gold to go forward to north sea vowing to in hearing that cared more for poverty than have cared for good name then being little apart from rest pointed round to green forest said in spanish suppose knew not that understood beee round be paradise be not enough for to stay here forever let take gold leave a will ' to mr oxenham 'those who lived in paradise have not sinned a have must never have grown old sick a will ' 'if do that there be poison enough in wood by may die in other arm a must to heaven have died seven year agone 'no life stand upon honor to fulfil bond with men whom have brought hither to take home to england at least something of prize a proof of own valor then smiling not prize enough proof enough must not be so tempted turning to offered half of treasure if must go back with rescue from spaniard at lady wept wailed much took upon to comfort though be simple mariner telling that stood upon mr oxenham honor that in england nothing be esteemed so foul a cowardice breaking word betwixt man man that better be for to die seven time by spaniard than to face at home scorn of who sailed sea so after much ado back went again penberthy three plymouth men escaped from pinnace keeping lady a before well sir waited five day having made house of bough a before without hearing aught on sixth saw coming afar off mr oxenham with fifteen twenty men who seemed very weary wounded when looked for rest to be behind behold there be more at sir a may well think heart sank within mr o coming nearer cried out afar off 'all be lost so walked into camp without word sat down at foot of great tree with head between hand speaking to lady to one till very pitifully kneeling before cursing for cause of mischief praying to avenge upon that tender body won hardly to look once upon after a be way of vain unstable man between be a before men be full of curse against negro for cowardice treachery yea against high heaven have put most part of ammunition into spaniard hand told believe truly how forced enemy awaiting in little copse of great tree well fortified with barricade of bough having with two falcon have taken out of pinnace how mr oxenham divided english negro into two band that one might attack enemy in front other in rear so set upon with great fury must have utterly driven out that negro who have come on with much howling like very wild beast being suddenly scared with shot noise of ordnance turned fled leaving englishman alone in evil strait mr o fought like very guy of warwick verily believe man of likewise for there be none of who have not shrewd scratch to show indeed mr oxenham party have once gotten within barricade spaniard being sheltered by tree trunk especially by one mighty tree stood a remembered remember now borne up two fathom high upon own root a be upon arch pillar shot at with such advantage that have several slain seven more taken alive only among root of tree so seeing that must prevail nothing having little pike sword be fain to give back though mr oxenham swore must not stir foot making at spanish captain be borne down with pike hardly pulled away by who at last reminding of lady persuaded to come away with rest whereon other party fled also what have become of knew not for took way so miserably drew off having lost in men eleven killed seven taken alive besides five of rascal negro who be killed before have time to run there be end of matter in document from have drawn veracious history note be appended to point of yeo story seems to to smack sufficiently of old elizabethan seaman to be inserted at length so far most after agreeth with lopez vaz tale taken from pocket by lord cumberland mariner at river plate in year note here vainglory falsehood else fear of spaniard first lest must be seen how great advantage spaniard have maketh mention of english calivers two piece of ordnance be in pinnace second saith nothing of flight of cimaroons though be evidently to be gathered from saith that of le than seventy english be slain eleven of negro five while of english seven be taken alive yet of negro none why because rascal ran thirdly be thing incredible out of experience that eleven english must be slain seven taken with loss only of two spaniard killed search now see for will not speak of mine own small doings in memorable voyage worthy learned mr hakluyt hath so painfully collected be to old age next only to bible whether in fight have endured with spaniard loss even in victory hath not far exceeded ours for be bigger of body fiercer of spirit being even to poorest of thanks so care of illustrious prince best fed men of europe most trained to feat of strength use of weapon put trust also not in virgin saint dead rag bone painted idol have breath in mouth st bartholomew medal such devil remembrancers in only true god lord jesus christ in whom trusteth one of will chase thousand so hold having have good experience say if have done once let do again kill eleven to two with weapon will save paper bullet blown out of fame lying trumpet yet have quarrel with poor portugal for doubt not friend lopez vaz have looking over shoulder a wrote mighty black velvet don with name a long a don bernaldino delgadillo de avellaneda who set forth lately vainglorious libel of lie concerning last fatal voyage of dear friend sir f drake sir john hawkins who rest in peace having finished labor a must god rested to whose shameless unspeakable lying good friend mr henry savile of county did most pithily wittily reply stripping as out of lion skin sir thomas baskerville general of fleet by advice send cartel of defiance offering to meet with choice of weapon in indifferent kingdom of equal distance from realm challenge hath prudently put in pipe rather rolled up for one of spanish cigarros smoked doubt not found foul in mouth next day gentleman in came five twenty more being wreck of other party with few negro last proved honester men than be brave for there being great misery among english one of straggling where must to get food day one more who went out never came back that caused suspicion that negro have betrayed to spaniard maybe slain eaten so fellow being upbraided with altogether left telling boldly that if have eaten fellow owed debt instead of spanish prisoner in great terror hunger went forward over mountain till came to little river ran northward seemed to lead into northern sea there mr o who sir will say after first rage be over behaved through like valiant skilful commander bade cut down tree make canoe to go down to sea began to do with great labor little profit hewing down tree with sword burning out with fire after much labor kindled a be burning out of first tree cutting down of great party of negro came upon with much friendly show bade flee for life for spaniard be upon in great force so be up away again hardly able to drag leg after for hunger weariness broiling heat be taken god help fled with negro of whom what became god alone knoweth eight ten held on with captain among whom be fled downward toward sea for one day afterwards finding by noise in wood that spaniard be on track of turned up again toward inland coming to cliff climbed up over drawing up lady little maid with cord of liana hang from tree a honeysuckle doe here exceeding stout long even to fifty fathom so breaking track hoped to be out of way of enemy by nevertheless only increased misery for two fell from cliff a men asleep for very weariness miserably broke bone others whether by great toil sunstroke eating of strange berry fell sick of flux fever where be drop of water rock of pumice stone a bare a back of hand full moreover of great crack black without bottom over have not strength to lift sick be fain to leave there aloft in sunshine like dive in torment cry aloud for drop of water to cool tongue man great stinking vulture two sitting by like ugly black fiend out of pit waiting till poor soul must depart out of corpse nothing must avail for dear life must down again into wood be burned up alive upon rock so getting down slope on farther side came into wood once more there wandered for many day know not how many shoe being gone clothes rent off with brake briar yet how lady endured be marvel to see for went barefoot many day for clothes be fain to wrap in mr oxenham cloak while little maid went naked ever looked still on mr oxenham seemed to take care a long a be by comforting cheering with pleasant word yea once sitting down under great fig tree sang to sleep with very sweet music yet waking about midnight saw sitting still upright weeping very bitterly on whom sir god have mercy for be fair brave jewel so to make few word of sad matter at last there be none left mr oxenham lady little maid together with william penberthy of marazion good comrade mr oxenham always led lady penberthy carried little maid for food have fruit such a must find water got from leaf of certain lily grew on bark of tree found by seeing monkey drink at little maid called monkey cup asked for continually making climb for so wandered on upward into very high mountain always fearing lest spaniard must track with dog made lady leap up often in sleep cry that bloodhound be upon befell upon day that came into great wood of fern grew not on ground like ours on stem a big a pinnace mast bark of be like fine meshed net very strange to see where be very pleasant shade cool green there gentleman sat down on bank of moss like folk desperate fordone one looked other in face for long while after took off bark of fern for must need be doing something to drive away thought began to plait slipper for little maid a be plaiting mr oxenham said 'what hinders from dying like men man falling on own sword ' to answered that dare not for wise woman have prophesied of sir must die at sea yet neither by water battle wherefore did not think right to meddle with lord purpose william penberthy said 'that must sell life that dear never give away ' lady said how gladly must die then la paouvre garse be in french 'the poor maid ' meaning little one then mr oxenham fell into very great weeping weakness never saw in before since with many tear besought never to desert little maid might befall promised swearing to like heathen must if have be able have kept like christian on sudden there be great cry in wood coming through tree on side spanish arquebusiers hundred strong at least negro with who bade stand must shoot william penberthy leapt up cry 'treason running upon nearest negro ran through then then falling on spaniard fought manfully till be borne down with pike so died seeing thing better to do sate still finished plaiting so be taken mr oxenham bound with cord soldier made litter for lady child by commandment of senor diego de tree commander very courteous gentleman well sir be brought down to place where house of bough have be by river side there went over in boat found waiting for certain spanish gentleman among others one old ill favored man gray bearded bent in suit of black velvet who seemed to be great man among if will believe mr leigh be none other than old man with gold falcon at breast don francisco xararte by name whom found aboard of lima ship have known a much of a do a mr oxenham did have cut up for shark bait ever let cur ashore again well sir a soon a lady came to shore old man ran upon sword in hand must have slain there held back on turned to reviled with foul spiteful word must think of so that there bade be silent for shame mr oxenham said 'it be worthy of don francisco thus to trumpet abroad own disgrace did not tell year ago that be cur be not proving word for ' answered 'english dog must to heaven have never seen mr oxenham bepanish ape must to heaven have sent dagger through herring rib when passed behind st ildegonde church eight year last easter eve ' at old man turned pale then began again to upbraid lady vowing that must have burnt alive other devilish word to answered at last 'must that have burnt alive on wedding morning spared eight year of misery beisery hear witch senor oh have not pampered heaped with jewel clothes coach what not saint alone know what ' have spent on what more must have of ' to answered only one word 'fool ' in so terrible voice though low that who be about to laugh at old pantaloon be more minded to weep for 'fool ' said again after while will waste word upon must have driven dagger to heart month ago be loath to set free so soon from gout rheumatism selfish stupid know when bought body from parent did not buy soul farewell love life farewell senor may be more merciful to daughter than parent be to ' so catching dagger from girdle of one of soldier smote to heart fell dead before at mr oxenham smiled said be worthy of if will unbind hand senor will be most happy to copy so fair schoolmistress don diego shook head said 'it be well for valiant senor be at liberty to do so on questioning of sailor whom have already taken can not hear that have letter of license from queen of england other potentate be compelled therefore to ask whether be so for be matter of life death ' to mr oxenham answered merrily that so be that be not aware that potentate license be required to permit gentleman meeting lady love that a for gold have taken if have never allowed that fresh fair young may to be forced into marrying that old january must never have meddled with gold so be rather fault than added that if be to be hanged a supposed only favor asked for be long drop priest while gentleman still kept eye fixed on lady corpse till be led away with while stood by god reward for lamented openly tragical end of two sinful lover now sir what befell after matter little for never saw captain oxenham again ever will in life be hanged then so heard for certain next year with gunner sundry more be given away for slave to spaniard may be alive now unless like have fallen into cruel clutch of inquisition for inquisition now gentleman claim body soul of heretic over world a devil told with own lip when pleaded be spanish subject none that catch whether peaceable merchant shipwrecked mariner must turn burn how did get into inquisition why sir after be taken set forth to go down river again old don took little maid with in one boat bitterly screeched at parting from from poor dead corpse mr oxenham with don diego de tree in in third from spaniard learnt that be to be taken down to lima to viceroy that old man lived hard by panama be going straight back to panama forthwith with little maid said 'it will be well for if ever get there for old man swears be none of must have left behind in wood now if don diego have not shamed out of ' when heard that seeing that there be nothing death before made up mind to escape very first night sir by god help did went southward away into forest avoiding track of cimaroons came to indian town there gentleman got more mercy from heathen than ever have from christian for when found that be spaniard fed gave house wife good wife be to painted over in pattern a see because have knowledge of surgery blood letting fleams in pocket be worth to fortune rose to great honor among though taught more of simple than ever taught of surgery so lived with merrily enough being very heathen like indeed worse for worshipped xemes nothing in time wife bare child in looking at whose sweet face gentleman forgot mr oxenham little maid oath ay native land also wherefore be taken from else have lived died a beast perish for one night after be lain down came noise outside town starting up saw armed men calivers shining in moonlight heard one read in spanish with loud voice fool sermon after custom when hunt poor indian how god have given to st peter dominion of whole earth st peter again indie to catholic king wherefore if must all be baptized serve spaniard must have monkey allowance other of more kick than penny if not then have at with fire sword dare say worship know that devilish trick of theirs better than know man go on well sooner be word spoken than without waiting to hear what poor innocent within must answer though mattered little for understood not one word of do villain let fly right into town with calivers then rush in sword in hand killing pell mell met one of shot gentleman passing through doorway close by struck poor wife to heart that never spoke word more catching up babe from breast tried to run when saw town full of dog with in leash be yet worse knew be lost sat down again by corpse with babe on knee waiting end like one stunned in dream for now thought god from whom have fled have surely found out a did jonah punishment of sin be come well gentleman dragged out young men woman chained together by neck one catching pretty babe out of arm call for water priest for have shavelings with sooner be christened than catching babe by heel dashed out brain oh gentleman gentleman against ground a if have be kitten so did to several more innocent night after have christened saying be best for to go to heaven while be still sure thereof so marched for slave leaving old folk wounded to die at leisure when morning came knew by skin be indian by speech be spaniard began threatening with torment till confessed be englishman one of oxenham crew at say leader will to lima to hang by side of captain pirate by first knew that poor captain be certainly gone ala for priest step in claim for booty calling lutheran heretic enemy of god so to make short sad story to inquisition at cartagena went where what suffered gentleman be a disgustful for to hear a unmanly for to complain of so be that being twice racked having endured water torment a best must be put to scarpines whereof be a see somewhat lame of one leg to day at must abide more so wretch that be denied god in hope to save life indeed did little profited for though have turned to superstition must have two hundred stripe in public place then go to galley for seven year there gentleman ofttimes thought that have be better for to have be burned at once for know a well a what floating hell of heat cold hunger thirst stripe toil be one of accursed craft in hell nevertheless gentleman found road to heaven have almost said heaven for fell out by god mercy that next comrade be englishman like young man of bristol who a told have be manner of factor on board poor captain barker ship have be preacher among anabaptist here in england oh sir richard grenville if man have done for what did for must never say word against who serve same lord because altogether hold with for from time to time sir seeing altogether despairing furious like wild beast in pit set before in secret earnestly sweet promise of god in christ who say 'come to ye be heavy laden will refresh though sin be a scarlet will be a white a snow till past sinful life of mine looked like dream when one awaketh forgot bodily misery in misery of soul so did loathe hate for rebellion against loving god who have chosen before foundation of world come to seek save when be lost falling into very despair at burden of heinous sin knew peace until gained sweet assurance that lord have hanged burden upon cross washed sinful soul in most sinless blood amen sir richard grenville said amen also gentleman if sweet youth won soul to christ paid a dearly for a ever did saint of god for after three four month when have be while in sweet converse with may say in heaven in midst of hell there came one night to barranco at lima where be kept when on shore three black devil of holy office carried off without word only saying to 'look that turn come not next for hear that have have much talk with villain at word be so struck cold with terror swooned right away verily if have taken there then must have denied god again for faith be young weak instead left aboard galley for few month more be whole voyage to panama back in daily dread lest must find in cruel claw again then nothing for to burn a relapsed heretic when came back to lima officer came on board again said to 'that heretic have confessed naught against so will leave for time because have be seen talking with so much holy office suspect conversion to be rotten one be adjudged to galley for rest of life in perpetual servitude ' what became of asked amyas be burned day two before got to lima five others with at same stake of whom two be englishman old comrade of mine a guess ah said amyas heard of when be off lima said too that there be six more lying still in prison to be burnt in few day if have have fleet with a must have have if have not be for john winter must have gone in rescued poor wretch sacked town to boot what must do with one ship must to god have sir for story be true enough among heard be two young lady of quality confessor who came to end for reproving out of scripture filthy loathsome living of part a saw well enough too well be liker to sodom than to christian town god will avenge saint sin amen amen said sir richard on with thy tale for be a strange a ever man heard well gentleman when heard must end day in galley be for awhile like madman in day two there came over know not how full assurance of salvation for life life to come such a have never have before be revealed to speak truth gentleman before heaven now have be tried to uttermost that deliverance be at hand way up to panama be after have laden 'cacafuogo cast in mind how to escape found way just a be beginning to lose heart again door be opened by lord own hand for know not why be marched across from panama to nombre have never happened before there put together into great barranco close by quay side shackled a be fashion to one long bar ran whole length of house very first night that be there looking out of window spied lying close aboard of quay good sized caravel well armed just loading for sea land breeze blew off very strong so that sailor be laying out fresh warp to hold to shore came into mind that if be aboard of must be at sea in five minute looking at quay saw soldier who have guarded scattered about drinking gambling going into tavern to refresh after journey be just at sundown hour after in come gaoler to take last look at for night key at girdle whereon sir whether by madness whether by spirit gave samson strength to rend lion rose against a passed without forethought treachery of kind chained though be caught by head threw there then against wall that never spoke word after then with key freed soul in room bid follow vowing to kill man who disobeyed command followed a men astounded leaping out of night into day death into life so aboard caravel out of harbor lord only know how who blinded eye of idolater 'with more hurt than few chance shot from soldier on quay tale have be over long already gentleman go on till midnight good fellow if will well sir chose for captain certain genoese for lieutenant away to go must fain have gone ashore after back to panama to hear news of little maid must have be fool errand wanted to turn pirate genoese too who be prudent man though evil one persuaded to run for england get employment in netherland war assuring that there must be safety in spanish main when once escape got wind more part being of one mind for england sailed watering at barbadoes because be desolate so eastward toward canary in voyage what endured being taken by long calm by scurvy calentures hunger thirst tongue can tell many time be glad to lay out sheet at night to catch dew suck in morning have noggin of rain water out of scupper be a much sought to a if have be adelantado of indie till of hundred forty poor wretch hundred ten be dead blaspheming god man above genoese for taking europe voyage a if have not sin enough of own already last of when thought safe be wrecked by southwester on coast of brittany near to cape race from nine soul of came ashore with life so to brest where found flushinger who carried to falmouth so end tale in if have said one word more le than truth can wish worse than to have to undergo second time voice a finished sank from very weariness of soul while sir richard sat opposite in silence elbow on table cheek on doubled fist looking through through with kindling eye one spoke for several minute then amyas have heard story believe word sir must not have heart of christian man so do anthony butler entered take man to buttery clothe comfortably feed with best bid knave treat a if be own father yeo lingered if might be so bold a to ask worship favor anything in reason brave fellow if worship must put in way of adventure to indie hast not have enough of spaniard already never enough sir while one of idolatrous tyrant be left unhanged said with right bitter smile be not for that only sir little maid oh sir little maid swore to mr oxenham to look to never saw from day to must find sir will go mad believe not night come call to in dream poor darling not morning when wake there be oath lying on soul like great black cloud nearer keeping of told that poor young minister of when be in galley together said oath be oath keep must keep will sir if will help have patience man god will take a good care of thy little maid a ever thou wilt know sir know be weak sir oh if be bred up papist idolater must her blood be on head then sir sooner than sooner than 'd be in inquisition again to morrow must good fellow there be adventure to indie forward now if want to fight spaniard here be gentleman will show way amyas take with to ireland if have learnt lesson god have set to learn ought to stand in good stead yeo looked eagerly at young giant will have sir there be few matter ca turn hand to maybe will be going to indie again day eh take with 'd serve turn well though say for gunner for pilot know stone tree from nombre to panama port of sea will never be content will warrant till have have turn along gold coast will now amyas laughed nodded bargain be concluded so out went yeo to eat amyas having received despatch got ready for journey home go short way over moor lad send back cary gray when can must not lose hour be ready to sail moment wind go about so started a amyas be getting into saddle saw that there be stir among servant who seemed to keep carefully out of yeo way whispering nodding mysteriously just a foot be in stirrup anthony old butler plucked back dear father alive mr amyas whispered be going by moor road alone with chap why not then be too big for to eat reckon oh mr amyas be not right tell not company for christian to go forth with creature a have flame of fire in inwards 't be temptation of providence indeed then be tale of tub tale of christian sir there be two boy pig minding seed at down hill beside maiden be taken mazed wonder poor soul lying in screeching asterisk now down to mill ask a go by saw flame come out of mouth of mun smoke out of mun nose like vire drake roaring of mun like roaring of ten thousand bull oh sir to go with after dark over moor 't be devil device sir against because be going against sarvants pope of room spaniard will be pixy led sure a life locked into bog will see mun vanish away to fire brimstone like jack o ' lantern oh have care then have care old man wrung hand while amyas bursting with laughter rode off down park with unconscious yeo at stirrup chatting away about indie delighting amyas more more by shrewdness high spirit rough eloquence have gone ten mile more day began to draw in western wind to sweep more cold cheerless moment when amyas knowing that there be not inn hard by around for many mile ahead took pull at certain bottle lady grenville have put into holster then offered pull also declined have meat drink too about heaven be praised meat drink fall to then man stand on manner whereon yeo seeing old decayed willow by brook went to took therefrom touchwood to set light with knife stone while amyas watched little puzzled startled a yeo fiery reputation came into mind be really salamander sprite going to warm inside by meal of burning tinder now yeo in solemn methodical way pulled out of bosom brown leaf began rolling piece of up neatly to size of little finger then putting one end into mouth other on tinder sucked at till be light drinking down smoke began puffing out again at nostril with grunt of deepest satisfaction resumed dog trot by amyas side a if have be walking chimney on amyas burst into loud laugh cried why wonder said breathed fire be not that indian tobacco yea verily heaven be praised did never see before never though heard talk of along coast took for one more spanish lie humph well live learn ah sir lie blessed truth a can tell who have ere now gone in strength of weed three day night without eating therefore sir indian always carry with on war party wonder for when thing be made none be made better than to be lone man companion bachelor friend hungry man food sad man cordial wakeful man sleep chilly man fire sir while for stanching of wound purging of rheum settling of stomach there be herb like unto under canopy of truth of eulogium amyas tested in after year a will be fully set forth in due place time mark in meanwhile say one of veracious chronicler from whom draw fact writing seemingly in palmy day of good queen anne not having a say before eye fear of misocapnic solomon james of other lying stuart not to south devon to north not to sir walter raleigh to sir amyas leigh not to bank of dart to bank of torridge doe europe owe day spring of latter age age of smoke will endure thrive when age of brass will have vanished like of iron of gold for whereas mr lane be said to have brought home divine weed a spenser well name from virginia in year be hereby indisputable that full four year earlier by bridge of putford in torridge moor true smoker will hereafter visit a hallowed spot point of pilgrimage first twinkled that fiery beacon beneficent lodestar of bidefordian commerce to spread hereafter from port to port peak to peak like watch fire proclaimed coming of armada fall of troy even to shore of bosphorus peak of caucasus farthest isle of malayan sea while bideford metropolis of tobacco saw pool choked with virginian trader pavement of bridgeland street groaning beneath savory bale of roll trinadado leaf pudding grave burgher bolstered blocked out of own house by scarce le savory stock fish cask filled cellar parlor attic be fain to sit outside door silver pipe in strong right hand left hand chinking cheerfully doubloon deep lodged in auriferous cavern of trunk hose while in fairy ring of fragrant mist circled round contemplative brow flitted most pleasant vision of wiltshire farmer jogging into sherborne fair heaviest shilling in pocket to buy unless old aubrey lie lotus leaf of torridge for weight in silver draw from thence after example of cacique of dariena supply of inspiration much needed then a now in gothamite region yet did improve a englishman upon method of heathen savage for latter so salvation yeo reported a truth dampier surgeon mr wafer after when will deliberate of war policy sit round in hut of chief where being placed enter to small boy with cigarro of bigness of rolling pin puff smoke thereof into face of warrior from eldest to youngest while putting hand funnel wise round mouth draw into sinuosity of brain that more than delphic vapor of prophecy boy presently fall down in swoon being dragged out by heel laid by to sober enter to puff at sacred cigarro till be dragged out likewise so on till tobacco be finished seed of wisdom have sprouted in soul into tree of meditation bearing flower of eloquence in due time fruit of valiant action with quaint fact for fact be in spite of bombast end present chapter chapter viii how noble brotherhood of rose be founded be virtue yea virtue gentleman maketh gentleman maketh poor rich base born noble subject sovereign deformed beautiful sick whole weak strong most miserable most happy there be two principal peculiar gift in nature of man knowledge reason one commandeth other obeyeth thing whirling wheel of fortune can change deceitful cavillings of worldling separate sickness abate age abolish lilly euphues now fall to lot to write of foundation of most chivalrous brotherhood of rose after few year made not only famous in native country of devon formidable a will be related hereafter in ireland in netherlands in spanish main heart of south america if chapter will seem to quixotic fantastical let recollect that generation who spoke acted thus in matter of love honor be nevertheless practised valiant soldier prudent crafty politician that who wrote arcadia be at same time in spite of youth one of subtlest diplomatist of europe that poet of faerie queene be also author of state of ireland if will quote against with sneer lilly euphues will only answer by asking have ever read for if have done so pity if have not found in spite of occasional tediousness pedantry a brave righteous pious book a man need look into wish for better proof of nobleness virtue of elizabethan age than fact that euphues arcadia be two popular romance of day may have suited purpose of sir walter scott in cleverly drawn sir piercie shafton to ridicule euphuists affectatam comitatem of travelled english of languet complains over above anachronism of whole character for to give one instance euphuist knight talk of sidney quarrel with lord oxford at least ten year before happened do deny that lilly book must if read by man of common sense produce coxcomb whose spiritual ancestor must rather have be gabriel harvey lord oxford if indeed former have not maligned latter ill tempered tom nash maligned maligner in turn indeed there be double anachronism in sir piercie for doe not even belong to day of sidney to worse time began in latter year of elizabeth after breaking mighty heart have full license to bear crop of fool head in profligate day of james of perhaps hereafter in meanwhile let who have not read euphues believe that if must train son after fashion of ephoebus to great saving of own money virtue father even in money making day must rise up call blessed let rather open eye see in old elizabeth gallant own ancestor showing forth with luxuriant wildness of youth virtue still go to making of true englishman let not only see in commercial military daring in political astuteness in deep reverence for law in solemn sense of great calling of english nation antitype rather example of own let confess that chivalry be only garb of beautiful tenderness mercy be now a be then twin sister of english valor even in extravagant fondness for continental manner literature let recognize that old anglo norman teachableness wide heartedness have enabled to profit by wisdom civilization of age of land without prejudice to own distinctive national character so go to story if one dislike have to turn leaf till find pasturage suit better amyas must not sail next day day after for southwester freshened blew three part of gale dead into bay so having got mary grenville down river into appledore pool ready to start with first shift of wind went quietly home when mother started on pillion behind old serving man to ride to clovelly where frank lay wounded went in with a far a bideford there met coming down high street procession of horseman headed by will cary who clad cap pie in shining armor sword on thigh helmet at saddle bow looked a gallant young gentleman a ever bideford dame peeped at from door window behind upon country pony came four five stout serving men carrying lance baggage own long bow sword buckler behind in horse litter to mr leigh great joy master frank deposed that wound be only flesh wound dagger having turned against rib that must see last of brother that with good leave must not come home to burrough take up abode with cary in ship tavern close to bridge foot did forthwith settling on couch held levee there in state mobbed by gossip of town not without white fib a to who have brought into sorry plight in meanwhile amyas concocted scheme be put into effect next day being market day first by innkeeper who began under amyas order bustle of roasting boiling frying unparalleled in annals of ship tavern next by amyas who going out into market invited a many of old schoolfellow one by one apart a frank have pointed out to to merry supper rowse thereon consequent by crafty scheme in came of rose salterne gentle admirer found to considerable disgust seated at same table with six rival to none of whom have spoken for last six month however be too well bred to let leigh discern a much though of course knew settled guest frank on couch lying at head of table amyas taking bottom contrived by filling mouth with good thing to save pain of speaking to other till wine must have loosened tongue warmed heart in meanwhile amyas frank ignoring silence of guest with most provoking good humor chatted joked told story made such good company will cary who always found merriment infectious melted into jest then into finding good humor far more pleasant than bad tried to make mr coffin laugh only made bow to make mr fortescue laugh only made frown unabashed nevertheless began playing light artillery upon waiter till drove out of room bursting with laughter so far so good when cloth be drawn sack sugar became order of day queen bible have be duly drunk with honor frank tried fresh move have toast gentleman here be 'the gentleman of irish war may ireland never be without st leger to stand by fortescue fortescue to stand by st leger chichester to stand by toast of course involved drinking health of three representative of family returning thanks paying compliment to other house so ice cracked little further young fortescue proposed health of amyas leigh bold mariner to amyas replied by few blunt kindly word that wished to know better fortune than to sail round world again with present company a fellow adventurer so give spaniard taste of men of devon by time wine going down sweetly caused lip of be asleep to speak till ice broke up altogether man began talking like rational englishman to man who sat next now gentleman said frank who saw that be fit moment for grand assault have planned all along let give health none of dare say will refuse to drink with heart soul a well a with lip health of one whom beauty virtue have so ennobled that in light shadow of lowly birth be unseen health of one whom must proclaim a peerless in loveliness be not that gentleman here have sister who might well challenge from girdle of venus yet what else dare say while same lovely lady who if use own mirror must need be far better judge of beauty than can be have in own hearing again again assigned palm to surely if goddess decide among question of golden apple paris must vacate judgment seat gentleman heart doubt not have already bid a unworthy lip do now to drink 'the rose of torridge ' if rose of torridge have walked into room must hardly have caused more blank astonishment than frank bold speech guest turned red pale red again looked at other a much a to say what right have one to drink lift glass will dash out of hand frank with sweet effrontery drank health of rose of torridge double health to worthy gentleman whosoever may be whom be fated to honor with love well done cunning frank leigh cried blunt will cary none of dare quarrel with now however much may sulk at other for there be none of will warrant think that like best of so be bound to believe that have drunk health round so have what better thing can do gentleman than to drink other health round likewise so show yourselves true gentleman true christian ay true lover for what be love let speak freely to gentleman guest what be love very inspiration of deity whose name be love be sure that not without reason did ancient feign eros to be eldest of god by whom jarring element of chaos be attuned into harmony order how then will lover make father of strife will psyche wed with cupid to bring forth cockatrice egg soul be filled with love likeness of immortal to burn with envy jealousy division distrust true rose have thorn leaf poison sting to nettle cupid have arrow hurl scorpion venus be awful when despised a daughter of proetus found handmaid be grace not fury surely who love aright will not only find love lovely become lovely also speak not to reprehend gentleman for to a piercing wit have already perceived to judge by honorable blush discourse tends to point if will permit to rock have know not by what divine good hap attained if indeed have attained be not about to be washed off again by next tide frank rapid fantastic oratory utterly unexpected a be have a yet left wit time to set temper on fire when weak from wound paused for breath there be haughty murmur from more than one young gentleman who took speech a impertinent interference with man right to make fool of mr coffin who have sat quietly bolt upright looking at opposite wall now rose a quietly with face tried to look utterly unconcerned be walking out of room minute lady bath prophecy about feast of lapithae might have come true frank heart head never failed mr coffin said in tone compelled that gentleman to turn round so brought under power of face none must have beheld for five minute borne malice so imploring tender earnest be dear mr coffin if earnestness have made forget even for moment bound of courtesy let entreat to forgive add to heavy grief heavy enough already grief of losing friend only hear patiently to end generously know will hear then if be still incensed can again entreat forgiveness second time mr coffin to tell truth have at time never be to court be therefore somewhat jealous of frank court talk court clothes court company moreover being eldest of guest only two year younger than frank be little nettled at being classed in same category with who be scarce eighteen if frank have given least hint seemed to assume own superiority have be lost when instead thereof sued in forma pauperis threw upon coffin mercy latter who be true hearted man enough after have known frank ever since of must walk have nothing to do to sit down again submit while frank went on more earnestly than ever believe believe mr coffin gentleman more arrogate to myself superiority over than doe sailor hurled on shore by surge fancy better than comrade who be still battling with foam for too gentleman let confess that by confiding in may perhaps win to confide in have loved ay do love where love also start be matter of wonder that sun have dazzled have dazzled that lodestone have drawn have drawn frown gentleman have learnt to love for loving what love to admire for admiring admire will not try same lesson so easy when learnt so blissful what breed more close communion between subject than allegiance to same queen between brother than duty to same father between devout than adoration for same deity will not worship for same beauty be likewise bond of love between worshipper lover see in rival not enemy fellow sufferer smile say in heart that though may worship one can enjoy that one man meat must be poison of rest be so though deny will anticipate own doom slay for fear of dying will make unworthy of from very eagerness to win show ourselves faithful knight by cherishing envy most unknightly of sin will dream with italian spaniard that can become more amiable in lady eye by becoming hateful in eye of god of other will love better if come to with hand stained in blood of whom love better than let recollect rather gentleman be sure that only chance of winning if be worth winning be to will what will honor whom honor love whom love if there be to be rivalry among let be rivalry in emulation in virtue let try to outstrip other in loyalty to queen in valor against foe in deed of courtesy mercy to afflicted oppressed thus love will indeed prove own divine origin by raising nearer to god whose gift be yet show more excellent way be charity why must not make common love to whom be unworthy to name sacrament of common love to other why must not follow heroical example of ancient knight who having one grief one desire one goddess held that one heart be enough to contain grief to nourish desire to worship divinity so uniting in friendship till became one soul in two body lived only for other in living only for vowing a faithful worshipper to abide by decision to find own bliss in hers whomsoever esteemed most worthy of love to esteem most worthy also count by choice bounden servant of whom mistress have condescended to advance to dignity of master a not without hope that will be outdone in generous strife do here promise to be faithful friend to ability hearty servant of who will be honored with love of rose of torridge ceased there be pause at last young fortescue spoke may be paying left handed compliment sir seems to that be so likely in case to become own faithful friend hearty servant even if have not borne off bell already while have be asleep that bargain be hardly fair between gay italianist country swain undervalue country dear sir set mind at rest know more of lady mind than do will know for sake of own peace have made vow to see to hear if possible tidings of till three full year be past dixi mr coffin rose gentleman may submit to be outdone by mr leigh in eloquence not in generosity if leaf part for three year do so also go in charity with mankind said cary give hand old fellow if be coffin be sawn out of wishy washy elm board right heart of oak be going too a amyas here can tell to ireland away to cool hot liver in bog like jack hare in march come give thy neif let part in peace be minded to have fought thee day must have be most happy sir said coffin now be love charity to blessed christmas afternoon light be fading down even song be done good folk of bideford be trooping home in merry group father with child lover with sweetheart to cake ale flapdragons mummer play happy sport of christmas night one lady only wrapped close in black muffler followed by maid walked swiftly yet sadly toward long causeway bridge led to northam town sir richard grenville wife caught up stopped courteously will come home with mr leigh said lady grenville spend pleasant christmas night mr leigh smiled sweetly laying one hand on lady grenville arm pointed with other to westward said can not well spend merry christmas night while sound be in ear whole party around looked in direction in pointed above head soft blue sky be fading into gray here there misty star peeped out to westward where down wood of raleigh closed in with of blue be webbed turfed with delicate white flake iridescent spot marking path by sun have sunk showed color of dying dolphin low on horizon lay long band of grassy green what be sound troubled mr leigh none of with merry heart ear dulled with din bustle of town have heard till moment yet now listen be dead calm there be not breath to stir blade of grass yet air be full of sound low deep roar hovered over down wood salt marsh river like roll of thousand wheel tramp of endless army what be thunder of mighty surge upon boulder of pebble ridge ridge be noisy to night said sir richard there have be wind somewhere there be wind now where boy be god help said mr leigh knew that spoke truly spirit of atlantic storm have sent forward token of coming in smooth ground swell be heard inland two mile away to morrow pebble be now rattling down with retreating wave might be leaping to ridge top hurled like round shot far ashore upon marsh by force of advancing wave fleeing before wrath of western hurricane god help boy said mr leigh again god be a near by sea a by land said good sir richard true be lone mother one have heart just now to go home pray so mr leigh went onward up lane spent night in listening between prayer to thunder of surge till be drowned long ere sun rose in thunder of storm where be amyas on same christmas afternoon amyas be sitting bareheaded in boat stern in smerwick bay with spray whistling through curl a shout cheerfully pull with will merry men never mind shipping sea cannon ball be cargo spoil by taking salt water mother presage have be true enough christmas eve have be last of still dark steaming night of early winter western gale have be roaring for last twelve hour upon irish coast short light of winter day be fading fast behind be leaping line of billow lashed into mist by tempest beside green foam fringed column be rushing up black rock falling again in thousand cataract of snow before be deep sheltered bay be not far up bay that can see for four mile out at sea begin sloping roof of thick gray cloud stretch over head up far away inland cutting cliff off at mid height hiding kerry mountain darkening hollow of distant firth into blackness of night underneath awful roof of whirling mist storm be howling inland ever sweeping before great foam sponge gray salt spray till land be hazy dim dun let howl on for there be more mist than ever salt spray made flying before gale more thunder than ever sea surge wakened echoing among cliff of smerwick bay along sand hill flash in evening gloom red spark never came from heaven for fort now christened by invader fort del oro where flaunt hated golden flag of spain hold san josepho eight hundred of foe three night ago amyas yeo rest of winter shrewdest hand slung four culverin out of admiral main deck floated ashore dragged up to battery among sand hill now will be seen whether spanish italian condottieri can hold own on british ground against men of devon small blame to amyas if be thinking not of lonely mother at burrough court of quick bright flash on sand hill on fort where salvation yeo be hurling eighteen pound shot with deadly aim watching with cool bitter smile of triumph flying of sand crashing of gabions amyas party have be on board at risk of life for fresh supply of shot for winter battery be out of ball have be firing stone for last four hour in default of better missile ran boat on shore through surf where cove in shore made landing possible almost careless whether stove not scrambled over sand hill with man brace of shot slung across shoulder amyas leaping into trench shouted cheerfully to salvation yeo more food for bull dog gunner plum for spaniard christmas pudding speak to man at business master amyas five mortal time have missed will have accursed popish rag down a be sinner down with then nobody want to shoot crooked take good iron to not footy paving stone believe sir that foul fiend be there turning of shot aside do thought saw once thank heaven here be ball again ah sir if one must cast silver one now stand by men once again be eighteen pounder roared away oh glory great yellow flag of spain streamed in gale lifted clean into air flagstaff then pitched wildly down head foremost far to leeward hurrah from sailor answered by soldier of opposite camp shook very cloud above ere echo have died away tall officer leapt upon parapet of fort with fallen flag in hand rearing a well a must upon lance point held firmly against gale while fallen flagstaff be raised again within in moment dozen long bow be bent at daring foeman amyas behind shouted shame lad stop let gallant gentleman have due courtesy so stopped while amyas springing on rampart of battery took off hat bowed to flag holder who a soon a relieved of charge returned bow courteously descended be by time dark firing began to slacken on side salvation brother gunner having covered up slaughtering tackle with tarpaulings retired for night leaving amyas who have volunteered to take watch till midnight rest of force having got scanty supper of biscuit for provision be running very short lay down under arm among sand hill grumbled to sleep have paced up down in gusty darkness for hour more exchanging passing word now then with sentinel when two men entered battery chatting busily together one be in complete armor other wrapped in plain short cloak of man of pen peace talk of be of siege of sally catapult bombard culverin simply of english hexameter fancy not gentle reader that two be therein fiddling while rome be burning for commonweal of poetry letter in same critical year be in far greater danger from same hexameter than common woe of ireland a raleigh called be from spaniard imitating classic metre versifying a be called in contradistinction to rhyming be becoming fast fashion among more learned stonyhurst others have tried hand at hexameter translation from latin greek epic seem to have be doggerel enough ever anon youthful wit broke out in iambic sapphics elegiacs what not to great detriment of queen english subject ear know not whether mr william webbe have yet given to world fragment of precious hint for reformation of english poetry to tune of own tityrus happily thou liest tumbling under beech tree cambridge malvolio gabriel harvey have succeeded in arguing spenser dyer sidney probably sidney sister whole clique of beau esprit round into following model of what might call tree laurel o bonny laurel needes to thy bowes will bowe knee vail bonetto after snubbing first book of elvish queene be then in manuscript a base declension from classical to romantic school now spenser perhaps in mere melancholy wilfulness want of purpose for have just be jilted by fair maid of kent be wasting mighty genius upon doggerel fancied antique piratical publisher bitter tom nash swears with likelihood that harvey did have just given to world three proper wittie familiar letter lately past between two university men touching earthquake in april last english reformed versifying have set town wit buzzing like swarm of fly being none other than correspondence between spenser harvey be to prove to world forever correctness melody of such line a for like magnifico not beck glorious in show in deede most frivolous not looke tuscanish always let pas alma mater have seen a bad hexameter since then matter be serious there be story know not how true spenser be half bullied into re writing faerie queene in hexameter have not raleigh true romanticist whose vein for ditty amorous ode be most lofty insolent passionate persuaded to follow better genius great dramatist have not yet arisen to form completely that truly english school of spenser unconscious of own vast power be laying foundation indeed be not till daniel twenty year after in admirable apology for rhyme have smashed mr campian eight several kind of classical number that matter be finally settled english tongue left to go road on heaven have started so that may excuse raleigh answering somewhat waspish to quotation of spenser from three letter of immerito g h tut tut colin clout much learning have made thee mad good old fishwife ballad jingle be worth sapphics trimeters 'riff raff thurlery bouncing ' hey have there old lad do mind that precious verse dear wat homer virgil dear ned petrarch ovid wat have that owe to ancient ancient quotha why legend of king arthur chevy chase too of even fellow sinner sidney can not deny that time hears even from blind fiddler stir heart like trumpet blast speak well of bridge that carry over man did find redcross knight in virgil dame a una in old ovid more than did pater credo renegado baptized heathen yet surely younger more barbarous taste must bow before divine antiquity imitate afar a dottrels do fowler if homer be blind lad why dost not poke out thine eye ay hexameter be of ancient house truly ned spenser running away have nowhere to run to a for joining irish have mind to turn pig amyas found a will be hereafter told pleasant company enough one morning raleigh entered have done good turn leigh if think one have talked st leger into making lieutenant giving custody of right pleasant hermitage castle shackatory other in midst of big bog where time will run swift smooth with between hunting wild irish snaring snipe drinking drunk with usquebaugh over turf fire will go quoth amyas anything for work so went took possession of lieutenancy black robber tower there passed rest of winter fighting hunting day chatting reading evening with senor don guzman who like good soldier of fortune made thoroughly at home general favorite with soldier at first indeed spanish pride stateliness amyas english taciturnity kept two apart somewhat soon began if not to trust at least to like other don guzman told amyas bit by bit who be of what ancient house of what poor one laughed over very small chance of ransom being raised certainty at least must not come for couple of year seeing that only de soto who have penny to spare be fat old dean at st yago de leon in caracas at place don guzman comrade at back into green gulf of primaeval forest never to emerge again golden phantom man devouring whose maw be never satiate with soul of hero fatal to spain more fatal still to england upon shameful day when last of elizabeth hero will lay down head upon block nominally for having believed what around believed likewise till found expedient to deny in order to curry favor with crowned cur than might be if have be bred up master over body soul of men in remote land where law order have never come look at desmond brought up savage among savage papist among papist despot among slave thousand easy maiden deeming honor to serve pleasure thousand wild ruffian deeming piety to fulfil revenge let be without sin among cast first stone ay went on raleigh to a conversation dropped what hadst thou be raleigh hadst thou be that desmond whose land thou now desirest what wilt thou be when thou hast will thy child sink downwards a noble baron sank will genius of tyranny falsehood find soil within thy heart to grow ripen fruit what guarantee hast thou for doing better here than who went before thee yet can not do justice love mercy can not establish plantation build sow make desert valley laugh with corn will not have spenser with to fill with noble thought raise soul to heroic pitch be not true knight errantry to redeem to peace use to glory of glorious queen whom god have given to generous soil more generous race trustful tenderhearted be none more if be fickle passionate will not that very softness of temper make so easily led to evil make a easy to be led towards good yes here away from court among people who must bless a benefactor deliverer what golden day might be mine yet be angel mask from same cunning fiend ambition stage will house be indeed house of god foundation of be loyalty bulwark righteousness not house of fame whose wall be of soap bubble floor sea of glass mingled with fire must be good great when will day come when will be content to be good yet not great like same simple leigh toiling on by side to do duty with more thought for morrow than bird of god greatness have tasted that cup within last twelve month do not know that be sweet in mouth bitter in belly greatness be not essex great john of austria great desmond great whose race three short year ago have stood for age higher than will ever hope to climb castle land slave by thousand five hundred gentleman of name who have vowed to forswear god before forswore well have kept vow now dead in turf hovel like coney in burrow leigh what noise be that irish howl fancied came from off bog may be only plover cry something not quite right sir captain to mind said ancient have ugly story here of puck banshee what not of ghost there be again wailing just like woman say banshee cried night before desmond be slain perhaps then one may be cry for baltinglas for turn be likely to come next not that believe in such old wife tale shamus man said amyas to guide do hear that cry in
